speechtext: [English)

Mr. Speaker, I rise to invite Canadians to celebrate the first annual Women's History Month this October as declared earlier this year by the Minister responsible for the Status of Women.
Throughout our history, women in Canada have shaped our society in countless ways: in the home, in the work place, as volunteers, reformers and leaders. However, all too often their contributions have been overlooked.
Coinciding with the annual commemoration of the women's rights victory know as the Persons case of October 1929, Women's History Month offers all Canadians a chance to explore women's lives and accomplishments, past and present.
This is an opportunity not to be missed, particularly for young Canadians. A knowledge of the strong and purposeful women in our lives broadens our visions of life's possibilities and inspires us to future action.
In this year of our 125th anniversary, women can continue to be nation builders. I urge women to participate in determining Canada's future by voting in the nation-wide referendum on constitutional renewal on October 26.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to offer my congratulations to the
International Hockey Hall of Fame located in Kingston as it has just been sanctioned as an official museum for international hockey by the International Ice Hockey Federation.
The Hall of Fame will now display items from all 40 member countries of the federation. It will also receive the rights to reproduce federation sports memorabilia for sale locally and internationally. Plans are in hand to develop world-wide tours to the museum and to create an archives and research centre.
The directors of the Hall of Fame are to be commended for their diligence and hard work over many years in achieving this distinction. I wish them every success. Their efforts will ensure that the international history of Canada's game will flourish. Canadians will always remember those immortal words of Foster Hewitt, so sweet to our ears, which were spoken 20 years ago this month: "Henderson has scored for Canada".

Mr. Speaker, I would like to challenge the media to provide a balanced and qualified debate on the national referendum. To begin with there seems to be a trotting out before the media an onslaught of no experts. I ask the media: Are there not any yes experts?
Why are provincial premiers not forced into the spotlight of public debate with the same effort as the saviour of the Canadian women's movement, Judy Re-bick? Why are members of Parliament not forced into debate with the same vigour as Deborah Coyne, whose claim to fame seems to come more from her social activities than her public achievements?
It is my opinion the media is either lazy or incompetent because I believe there are two sides to the coin of this debate. It is unfortunate that all we seem to get today is the tail side.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to praise a government program, the older worker adjustment program, better known as POWA. This program provides permanently laid off older workers 70 per cent of their UI benefits from age 55 to 65; but there are problems with the program.
The economy is sour and the unemployment rate is at historically high levels. People can wait for two years before their applications are reviewed. Many of these people put their lives on hold, anticipating a positive response which may in fact not materialize.
The backlog in Ontario alone constitutes over 700 companies, affecting thousands of individuals. Current funding provisions address only about one-third of those laid off older workers.
Finally, the criterion that must be changed is the one that states the lay-off must be large relative to the size of the community. This discriminates against the smaller firms and their employees. Whether the lay-offs are 45 at a bakeiy, 20 at a dairy, 100 at a veneer mill, or 1,000 at a large industrial giant, all are laid off and should be eligible for POWA.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Canada round of constitutional talks has been a fair and open process in which every Canadian has had the chance to speak about their vision of Canada.
The last segment of this process will end on October 26, 1992, with a national referendum where all Canadians will have the opportunity to show their support.
The constitutional proposals reached in the Charlottetown agreement on August 28 serve as a reasonable compromise and as the basis for renewed federalism. No one present at these discussions left the table with everything they wanted. There were compromises made on all sides.
I feel these proposals represent the best possible solution to a very complicated and very serious issue. I am pleased that on Friday of this week the two provincial members of Parliament, the chief of the Chippewa band
and the mayors of Sarnia, Point Edwards, Moore Township, and myself will be making a joint public statement of support for these proposals and a continued united Canada.

Mr. Speaker, Canada Post is being stubborn and arrogant by refusing to co-operate and act on a request by the municipal council of Tracadie-Sheila that residents be able to address their mail so as to reflect the new municipality formed by merging the village of Sheila and the town of Tracadie.
In response to this legitimate and reasonable request, Canada Post insists that mail addressed to Tracadie-Sheila must be rejected. This attitude and this lack of sensitivity have increased the frustration and dissatisfaction of customers in my riding who see the closing of the Bas-Caraquet and Bertrand post offices as part of a strategy that is making dramatic inroads in the quality of service offered in the Acadian peninsula.
The Government of New Brunswick legislated the merger of the two municipalities of Tracadie and Sheila, and Canada Post should take steps to clear up the confusion it caused and observe the wishes of the residents of Tracadie-Sheila.

Mr. Speaker, the first annual Women's History Month to be held this October was announced earlier this year by the Minister responsible for the Status of Women, and I now wish to pay tribute to a number of French Canadian women who helped build our country.
As nun and teacher, Marguerite Bourgeoys founded the Congregation de Notre-Dame de Montreal in 1671, to educate young girls. She was canonized in 1982. As the owner of a sawmill and administrator of real property in the 18th century, Louise de Ramezay was one of the first business women in New France.
September 16, 1992

At the beginning of this century Marie-Lacoste-Gerin-Lajoie worked hard to improve the legal status of married women in Quebec. She was also a co-founder of the Federation nationale Saint-Jean-Baptiste.
Emilie Fortin-Tremblay was the first white woman to cross the Chilcoot Pass during the Klondike gold rush.
And Therese Casgrain led the struggle by Quebec women to obtain the franchise, which they did in 1940.
These are only a few examples of French Canadian women whose lives are an inspiration to us all. The women of Canada, whatever their ethnic origin, have made their mark in the past and they will continue to do so in a modem and prosperous Canada that is making its influence felt throughout the world.

Mr. Speaker, a very difficult situation has arisen involving a Canadian citizen who plays professional hockey in Italy. Jim Bodden was playing a regular season game on January 15 of this year in which a player from the other team died. The players were in front of the net, the other player punched Jim in the head and Jim reacted by shoving him away with his stick. Shortly thereafter the player died of a heart attack. The deceased player had suffered from epilepsy.
Jim is 29 years old and has played in Italy for the past 15 years. He is known to be a real gentleman on the ice. The Italian authorities are now saying that Jim will be charged with homicide. In that Jim and his family are Canadian citizens, I call upon the Secretary of State for External Affairs to contact our embassy in Italy to make certain that Jim Bodden's rights are being protected and that he is being treated fairly.
I would like to ensure that the Government of Canada's full resources are behind him and his family.

Mr. Speaker, the National Hockey League season begins in 23 days in Ottawa, but sports lovers on the Quebec side of the Ottawa River are very concerned about what seems to await them with the Ottawa Senators' threat to black out hockey on TVA and TQS during the week.
I have received many calls from sports fans in the Outaouais who ask me to intervene with the Minister of Fitness and Amateur Sport. In a letter that I sent him today, I ask him to intervene with Molson Breweries and the Ottawa Senators so that the people of the Outaouais are not hostage to such a decision and deprived of the television coverage of some 50 games of the Montreal Canadiens and Quebec Nordiques. While pressure is being put on Molson's and the Senators, I trust that action by the minister will bring results.
In closing, we must keep in mind that not everyone can afford hockey tickets.

Mr. Speaker, as the Atlantic salmon season in eastern Canada draws near a close, it is important to recognize the constructive conservation measures that have been achieved during 1992. To be sure, there will always be management challenges to face on behalf of this precious resource, but a firm foundation has now been laid for the regeneration of future salmon stocks in the years to come.
Foremost among the measures introduced this year was the minister's difficult and forthright decision to extend the closing of commercial fishing in the offshore waters of Newfoundland. This has dramatically amplified the impact of previous such closings in the maritime provinces and there was clear evidence of significantly increased salmon runs in almost all of the rivers on Canada's Atlantic seaboard in the past summer.
An equally difficult and comprehensive initiative has been the development of the aboriginal fishery strategy for Atlantic Canada which was announced just one week ago. This plan to fully involve native bands in management and guardianship of the resource as well as in the

September 16, 1992
rational economic exploitation of it should prove a most constructive approach in all respects. Not only does it point to improved sharing of the salmon harvest among all user groups, it emphasizes new harvesting directions to eventually eliminate gill-nets and to replace them with methods that are consistent with the catch and release conservation practices.
Along with these two major achievements, the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans deserves the genuine appreciation of all Canadians for the spirit of environmental responsibility which he has demonstrated through the over-all policy of his department for its sound salmon management in Canadian rivers.

Mr. Speaker, Ernst Zundel is a leading Nazi apologist and propagandist. He has promoted the lie that the Holocaust is a hoax, the gas chambers a matter of the imagination. Zundel was brought before Ontario's courts and was twice convicted for his pamphlet Did Six Million Really Die. He has been fined in his native Germany for hate crimes. When the Supreme Court struck down the Criminal Code section under which he was convicted, he hailed the decision as an affirmation of freedom of expression. We must ask: What sort of freedom and for what sort of expression?
The extreme right has already been aided and abetted by the decision. This week, on a new Klan hate line operating in Toronto, B'nai Brith human rights activist Ian Kagedan was denounced for stands taken in defence of human dignity.
For this and other racist fronts, freedom includes freedom to vilify and expression includes the dissemination of lies.
The message must come through loud and clear. We will not tolerate the promotion of hatred against any identifiable groups which will fray our social fabric. The cost of racism is incalculable. We must devote all our efforts and energies to eradicate this scourge.

Mr. Speaker, the B.C. salmon industry is in trouble.
Yesterday, the minister said that the disappearance of salmon from the Fraser River could have been due to the water being wanner than usual; warm but not warm enough to cook into oblivion 1.2 million sockeye salmon.
He said the count could have been wrong. His staff told me for three weeks they could have been 10 per cent or 15 per cent out, but to be 1.2 million out they would have to have been 80 per cent wrong. They denied any possibility of that.
This same minister said that B.C. salmon is not in trouble. The same person in a previous capacity three years ago said that the Atlantic cod was not in trouble. Look where we are today.
Three hundred fishing boats with hundreds of fishermen turned out yesterday to blockade B.C. harbours to prove that the minister is wrong and to draw attention to it. We need the committee to go out there and get a first-hand report. We need a judicial inquiry that will us what is wrong so that we can correct things for next year.
The B.C. salmon industry is in trouble.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to ask that Canada turn its eyes to a small nation in southeast Asia, Cambodia.
In 1975 the Khmer Rouge came to power in Cambodia, and before they were ousted in 1979 by the Vietnamese they had killed one million of their own people.
The United Nations is now in the middle of a delicate negotiating dance with the four political factions which want to govern Cambodia, including the Khmer Rouge and the present Vietnamese backed government.
The UN is starting Cambodians down the long road to democracy. Nation-wide elections are supposed to take place next spring under the guidance of the United Nations Transitional Authority of Cambodia. The Khmer

September 16, 1992

Rouge are once again threatening the life of this small nation by blocking the negotiations.
Canada must support the United Nations in its efforts and encourage Cambodians to resist the threats of the Khmer Rouge. The lives of seven million Cambodians hang in the balance. Canada can do no less.
Mr. Speaker, I rise as a Canadian woman to voice my disagreement with the National Action Committee on the Status of Women and its constitutional stance.
Hear, hear.

We have looked at the Canada clause. We have examined the charter and we have consulted with some of the top constitutional lawyers in the country, lawyers who are, may I add, committed feminists.
The result? We fail to see just how the gloomy scenarios for women depicted by NAC will be the product of this reform. We do not see how the Canada clause will endanger women's equality as guaranteed in sections 15 and 28 of the charter. We do not believe that women will be losers in a renewed Canada.
With the greatest of respect for the legal skills and capabilities of those advising NAC, I and many Canadian women simply cannot subscribe to this theory.
Hear, hear.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the Prime Minister.
On Saturday I had the occasion to meet 500 employees of Canadian Airlines in Vancouver who are willing to make some sacrifices in order to make sure that they preserve their jobs, the company and at the same time help to maintain competition in the air in Canada.
Oral Questions
I would like to know from the Prime Minister if this government has any policy to help them to maintain their company as other employees have succeeded in doing in the United States.

Mr. Speaker, several months ago, the two airlines had already begun to consider various proposals to ensure their survival. Canadian Airlines is now holding discussions with both Air Canada and American Airlines to see which of the two options would be more profitable and more likely to give the travelling public an efficient, competitive transportation system and at the same time to keep job losses in the aviation industry to a minimum.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will rephrase my question for the minister. I asked a question about the proposal from employees who are prepared to make sacrifices to keep their jobs.
In his reply the minister made no reference at all to the employees' proposal. Is the minister interested in the employees' proposal or is the government's pjolicy already made, that there will no longer be two airlines in Canada but only one?

Mr. Speaker, since the proposed agreement between American and Canadian is based on the new proposal made by the employees, Canadian has stated publicly that it was still examining this position in order to keep job losses to a minimum. We have already shown our interest in this proposal by completing the purchase of three R-310 Airbuses as quickly as possible so that Canadian Airlines has the funds it needs to continue to negotiate, safe from any surprises.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the minister.
According to the employees that I met in Vancouver, the Governments of Alberta and Manitoba, were ready to put some money on the table but that the Government of British Columbia, the province where most of the jobs are, refused completely to help in the situation.

Oral Questions
Was the minister in touch with the NDP Government of B.C. to do something for the 6,000 employees in British Columbia?

Mr. Speaker, I repeat again, in case the Leader of the Opposition did not hear, that when this proposal was originally presented to the various governments, the Government of Canada was the only one that agreed to invest in the purchase of three Airbuses, precisely to give Canadian Airlines all the breathing room and time it needs to examine all these options.

Mr. Speaker, my question is also for the Minister of Transport.
In 1991 the Conference Board of Canada produced a study entitled "The Tkx Competitiveness of the Canadian Airline Industry". In that study it concluded:
The principal reason for the uncompetitiveness of the Canadian airline system is the higher commodity sales tax on fuel.
How can the minister say that the government has done everything it can for a competitive airline industry when its own tax policies have undermined the ability of Air Canada and Canadian Airlines to compete?

Mr. Speaker, it is very well known that if the taxation level of Canadian corporations in Canada is at its present level, it is because of the huge deficit, the national debt that we have inherited from the previous Liberal government.
Last year we did in fact move in the taxation field by reducing the excise tax on fuel for the transportation industry from four cents to one cent on a temporary basis. We have changed the depreciation, the cost allowance configuration. This has helped the airline industry. We are continuing to examine the situation, not only for the airline but for the whole transportation industry.

Mr. Speaker, the minister is going to be examining the situation until there is no situation left to examine.
The Canadian Airline employees council has made major efforts to save its airline. It has proposed and been
willing to accept sacrifices and concessions. Five of the six unions at Canadian Airlines have indicated that they are willing to help. Provincial governments have indicated that they are willing to help.
What is this minister willing to do for the thousands of Canadian Airline employees and Air Canada employees who are concerned about their jobs being lost?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to point out to my hon. colleague that I did not say we were only studying. I said that we had already taken action to reduce the tax burden on airlines, as well as on all other transport companies, in particular by reducing the excise tax on gasoline and, among other things, by introducing the GST which has saved the airlines $250 million.

Mr. Speaker, all members of the House, and indeed all Canadians, will realize what a delicate and sensitive position our country is in at the moment.
My question is directed to the Prime Minister who will know that the three political parties of Canada have called a political cease-fire in their partisan activities in the best effort to work together for the yes campaign in an effort to keep our country together.
The Prime Minister will also know that NAFTA as a trade deal is divisive, is controversial, and has major political overtones. We already know that a major government advertising program is under way to promote NAFTA throughout the country.
In the best interest of ensuring a yes vote at this veiy critical time, would the Prime Minister be willing to pull the government's aggressive advertising campaign until after October 26 to allow the minimum amount of divisiveness and the minimum amount of political overtones attached to this and to allow us to get on with encouraging unity in our country?

Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. friend for his question.
September 16, 1992

As I understand it, the ads in regard to NAFTA are largely explanatory. They are trying to set out the advantages that might flow from the new trade agreement.
My hon. friend knows that almost 80 per cent of Mexican products presently enter Canada duty-free. If this agreement is ratified by the three Parliaments it will not have a perceptible effect, for example, on Canada's trading relationship. It will however open a new export market to us in a very considerable way. For every-
That is propaganda and that is where the problem is. You are making it worse.
My hon. friend says that it is propaganda. I was just about to say that for every billion dollars of exports Canada is able to realize 15,000-
Oh, oh.
The right hon. Prime Minister has the floor in answering a question. I know that hon. members would want to restrain their remarks.

I was going to make an observation before I was so rudely interrupted by my friend from Victoria. If my hon. friend would care to point out to me anything particularly objectionable or unacceptable, as I have not seen anything to which he refers, I would be happy to take a look at it.
Obviously, without trying to offend the great degree of unanimity that has been brought about in respect of the unity file, the operations of the Government and the Parliament of Canada continue to function within the normal constraints. However I would be happy to look at any objections my hon. friend has.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister will know that the House is planning to recess to allow all members to participate full time in selling the yes campaign, or almost all members. He will also know from the transcript that was leaked a couple of days ago that the campaign is aggressively under way, a massive advertising campaign is under way. He will also know that the other day his House leader said: "In order to win the NAFTA campaign we have got to create enemies".
I ask the Prime Minister this: Is this the time-

Oh, oh.
Oral Questions
Order, please.

Perhaps there were others as well who indicated the need to create enemies in order to win the NAFTA advertising campaign and convince people of the best interest of NAFTA.
In all seriousness, and to the Prime Minister, we know that as the days progress this gets to be a more challenging issue for the yes campaign. We also know-there is no question in this House-that the more we discuss NAFTA and the more the government forces NAFTA on to the front burner and on to the agenda there will be aggressive reaction across the country from those opposing it.
Surely the Prime Minister cannot believe that at this sensitive moment this is in the best interest of the unity file, as he refers to it. But for the future of our country will the Prime Minister pull back on his aggressive campaign to allow all members to work together, shoulder to shoulder to shoulder, in the best interests of our country?

Mr. Speaker, I look forward to working very closely with my hon. friend-I am going to British Columbia on Sunday and Monday-with regard to this great question of national unity.
My hon. friend made a statement I found quite startling, that our House leader said we had to create enemies. That is the one thing this government does not have to go out and create. I will have to talk to the House leader after this. That would be overkill.
I see the point my hon. friend is making and it is a serious point. A few weeks ago his leader said that when she undertook her national unity campaign she planned to campaign very actively against NAFTA and other things while she was giving her national unity message. I did not complain. If she chooses to do that, that is fine by me, but I do not plan to campaign in terms of national unity in favour of NAFTA or anything else. I am just going to campaign in favour of Canada and I will look forward to doing that in British Columbia with my hon. friend who has campaigned very hard on behalf of national unity in the past.

Mr. Speaker, I say to my hon. friend, the Prime Minister, that there is a world of difference between political leaders articulating their parties' views on critical trade issues and the government

Oral Questions
launching a massive, aggressive, brutal campaign and using taxpayers' money on a divisive issue.
I know the Prime Minister will be out there promoting this unity campaign. Across the street there is a whole organization that is out there now contacting companies across the country, aggressively encouraging them to support this divisive trade deal.
If the Prime Minister really believes that we must work co-operatively, if he really believes that all parties must set aside their political differences, create a political cease-fire until October 26-
I think the question has been put.

Mr. Speaker, my friend referred to a massive, aggressive and brutal campaign. I think I can give my hon. friend the assurance that there will be no brutal campaign. There will be no aggressive campaign. There will be no massive campaign. There will be a campaign designed to provide the Canadian people with some basic information regarding this deal.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister should be aware that just this morning the Canadian steel industry had to initiate yet another anti-dumping action against the United States because this government has failed to protect Canadian steel workers.
In fact the Canadian vice-president of Dofasco said yesterday:
If NAFTA does not improve, and in fact weakens, what we got under the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, we would be deceiving ourselves by supporting it.
Why has this government failed to protect Canadian steel workers and agreed to a deal which ignores the concerns of Canadian steel companies in anti-dumping and unfair pricing?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the minister of trade I will reply to the question that was posed.
First, the comments the hon. member raises are not accurate. We still have provisions in chapter nineteen to provide for a continuation of our consultations with the United States on the steel issue. More important, in addition, under the new agreement we have a new provision which will allow work to take place on the issue of replacing the anti-dumping laws with competition laws. That is exactly what the steel industry has been after for a long period of time.
We are answering their concerns. I might also say that anti-dumping charges are in fact brought by industries, not by government. It was the right of the steel industry to bring that charge.

Mr. Speaker, in fact it is the Canadian steel industry that is saying this.
Not only Dofasco has criticized the deal. Stelco said:
NAFTA essentially abandoned the commitment that was made
under the free trade agreement. We're very concerned that the
negotiators have overlooked something that is very important.
I want to ask the Prime Minister again: Why has the government agreed to a deal with the U.S. and Mexico that leaves tens of thousands of Canadian steel workers out to dry?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will repeat what I said. We have not. We have in fact responded to the steel industry's concerns in this agreement. It is there and the objectives are exactly the same as they were in the free trade agreement which it supported. It wanted change from anti-dumping law to competition law. Those clauses are contained in the NAFTA agreement.
We are doing what the steel industry has requested, exactly. I might add that we also have worked very hard in the multilateral trade negotiations in changing from an anti-dumping law to a competition law as well. We are very active in those negotiations as well.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday I asked the Minister for International Trade to table all the impact studies the government has prepared on the North American free trade agreement. What the
September 16, 1992

minister tabled yesterday is certainly not that. It is little more than propaganda financed by the taxpayer.
How can the government make its blanket assertions about the North American free trade agreement, the benefits to Canada, let alone design the adjustment assistance programs that Canadians badly need if what was tabled yesterday constitutes all the impact studies this government has prepared?
My question is a simple one. Is what was tabled yesterday the full extent of the government's impact studies of the North American free trade agreement? Yes or no.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, with the hon. member's permission, I am sure he will understand that I cannot respond to that.
The Minister for International Trade is away on government business today but will be back in the House later this week and will be able to answer that question specifically.

Mr. Speaker, that answer seems to me quite unsatisfactory because the minister knows whether he is the minister of trade or not.
The minister will recall that earlier this year, as a result of the utilization of the Freedom of Information Act, copies of preliminary impact studies, prepared for example by the Department of Agriculture, Investment Canada and Energy, Mines and Resources, were obtained.
Why does the government not table its final impact studies? Is the government saying in the answer from the minister: I cannot table anything; I do not know whether there is anything?
He knows there are impact studies. He knows he can table them or, in refusing to do so, is he merely leaving the Canadian people to utilize once again the Freedom of Information Act to obtain basic information, as the Prime Minister says, about the North American free trade agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is accusing me of something, I believe unfairly. The hon. member has been around here a very long period of time
Oral Questions
and understands that a question that specific should be directed to the minister responsible and not asked when he is out of the House.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for whoever is answering on behalf of the Minister of National Health and Welfare. Today in St. John's he said he wishes he could increase child benefits to $1,000 a month, but he said the government does not have the resources to do so.
Yesterday information obtained under the Access to Information Act shows that the government has spent $50,000 for a logo for the Brighter Futures program for children at risk. That is just one part of the $8 million budget for advertising and public relations for this program.
If the government is really serious about improving benefits for poor children, would it not be better to stop wasting taxpayers' money on logos and propaganda and start spending the $8 million on children instead? Why not stop feeding advertisers and start feeding children?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think everybody in this House would want to have more money to spend on children.
One thing we are debating today in the House is a bill on the child benefit package which was announced last February. It puts $2.1 billion of new money into child benefit programs.
We are putting a monthly cheque that is non-taxa-ble-and this is the first time that a child benefit program has been non-taxable-into the hands of parents. The money is targeted for those that really need it, and I think the hon. member should be very pleased.

Mr. Speaker, first the parliamentary secretary did not answer the question about the waste on advertising instead of putting money into government programs.
Just to put this into perspective, the $50,000 for this logo would feed 2,000 people at the Saskatoon Food

September 16, 1992
Oral Questions
Bank, 56 per cent of whom would be children, for a year. Maybe that is a priority the government should put first.
My supplementary question is for the Minister responsible for the Status of Women. The minister will know that the Canadian Child Day Care Advocacy Association was denied $23,000 under the women's program of the Secretary of State for a national child care conference, part of $300,000 of worth-while projects turned down this summer.
I wonder if the minister would not agree that Canadian women and children would be better served if funds were allocated to supporting worth-while projects instead of using taxpayers' dollars to promote the government's re-election program.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as my hon. colleague is aware, the women's program comes under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of State, who is not here today.
I would like to remind my hon. colleague that under the women's program there are many applications for excellent projects. The program, while it has had increased funding over the past several years, is not able to fund them all and decisions on priorities must be made. Priorities have been established to provide particular focus on women who are especially disadvantaged and those are the major projects that are being funded this year.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister.
In Quebec today more than 400,000 people are unemployed, more than 423,000 are on welfare and nearly
350,000	people who live alone are poor. It seems 53 per cent of Quebecers are afraid of losing their jobs, and meanwhile this government refuses to launch an economic recovery program.
How will the Prime Minister explain to millions of Canadians who are suffering as a result of his erroneous policies that he has no money for a program to modernize infrastructures, as proposed by the Leader of the
Opposition, but can afford to spend million of dollars on selling free trade which is losing us jobs?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I might remind the hon. member that in the February budget the Minister of Finance spelled out very clearly that he was prepared to discuss with the provinces a program to improve the national highway system. Those discussions are ongoing.
The ministers of transport of the provinces and of Canada will be discussing how that might be carried out at a meeting, I believe, within the next few days.
Thlks are going on to improve our national highway system and also to provide employment.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition proposed modernization of the infrastructure of the country in January. It is now the middle of September and time the government stopped discussions and started acting. People want jobs. They want to work today, not in two months.
When will the government announce a program for Canadians to work? Do we have to wait another six months?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I find it passing strange that when the Government of Canada announces programs which will create employment, such as purchasing helicopters for the armed forces, purchasing armoured cars, purchasing trucks from the west which preserve and create employment. They object to them.
Those purchases create employment in this country and it is the taxpayers' dollars being spent to create employment. It is billions of dollars. They object to that, and yet they want a make work project that will only provide jobs for a short period of time. What we are trying to do is create meaningful employment on the long term.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of fisheries. On June 2 the minister announced the northern cod moratorium response package which would look after roughly 19,000 plant workers and fishermen. Yesterday

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a special honour for me to inform the House today of the plans for dedicating Canada's peacekeeping monument. It will take place in Ottawa on October 8.
As many hon. members know, Canada's servicemen and servicewomen have a distinguished record in peacekeeping, spanning 45 years. In fact, Canada has participated in every peacekeeping mission mounted by the United Nations, and in seven non-UN missions as well.
That is a record unsurpassed by any other nation. Almost 90,000 Canadians have served in these missions over the years.

There are now more than 2,000 members of the Canadian Armed Forces involved in peacekeeping activities in 14 regions around the world, not to mention the 750 military we promised to send to Somalia and the 1,200 peacekeepers we offered to post in Yugoslavia.

Peacekeeping efforts of the United Nations have made such a profound mark on the world that in 1988 all UN peacekeepers were honoured with the award of the prestigious Nobel Peace Prize.
From this great tribute came the inspiration for a national monument in Ottawa to honour the contributions of Canadian Forces to peacekeeping. A national design competition under the auspices of the Department of National Defence and the National Capital Commission was held, and an independent jury comprised of prominent Canadians was appointed to make the final selection.
The jury received eight excellent submissions, and I am told that any one of them would have served the cause well. It is with some pride that I note that the winning design team is from British Columbia.
"The Reconciliation" is a most appropriate name for this winning entry, which was submitted by sculptor Jack Harman, urban designer Richard Henriquez and landscape architect Cornelia Hahn Oberlander.
The monument, which is now almost completed on Confederation Boulevard in front of the National Gallery, consists of two converging limestone walls-representative of opposing factions. The debris of war lies between these walls. Three cast bronze figures, representing the peacekeepers, will stand on an elevated wall.
The first of these, a communication servicewoman, recognizes a key role that Canadians often play in peacekeeping missions. The second figure, an officer wearing the traditional blue beret, portrays a United Nations military observer. The third bronze figure is of a sentry carrying a rifle, illustrating that peacekeeping is often a precarious and difficult job.
Just beyond the walls is a grove of 12 oak trees, a reminder that our peacekeepers come from all 10 provinces and our two territories. The grove will also serve as a symbol of our future and of our hope for peace.
On October 24 the whole world celebrates United Nations Day. What better month to be unveiling this

Routine Proceedings
unique Canadian monument to our peacekeepers? I hope that this year all Canadians will join in celebrating our own very special national peacekeeping day when we unveil our peacekeeping monument on October 8.
Beginning on October 1 all Canadian forces members who have served on United Nations peacekeeping duties at any time will begin wearing their blue berets. They will do so up to and including National Peacekeeping Day on October 8. This will serve as a positive sign to all members of the forces, and to all Canadians, that peacekeeping is an important facet of our defence policy and of Canada's commitment to world peace.
I am sure that the peacekeeping monument, located on Confederation Boulevard with such landmarks as the Parliament Buildings, the Supreme Court, the National War Memorial and the Canadian Museum of Civilization, will soon be recognized as a national symbol of Canada's dedication to peace.
Canada is the first country to dedicate such a monument to this important cause. Mr. Speaker, I am sure that you will agree that our peacekeepers should be first in our hearts and minds not only on October 8, but every day throughout the year.

Mr. Speaker, it is a special honour for me today to rise on behalf of the Liberal Party of Canada to respond to the fine address given by my colleague, the hon. Associate Minister of National Defence, giving tribute to peacekeepers and informing the House of the details of the peacekeeping monument that will be dedicated on October 8.
In my remarks I would like to reflect a little on what peacekeeping has meant and means. Despite the end of superpower rivalry the world remains a very dangerous place, and Canadians must, and should be, ever aware of this.
One of the pillars of our way of life is that we be secure. Total security involves not just military defence, but the social, economic, environmental and other factors for a secure and stress-free life.
Today Canada's primary concerns with defence involve not just sovereignty. They include concerns with the defence of the values, the institutions and the processes that define free societies. These now more than ever demand vigorous protection.
An ideal world that abolishes famine, disease, poverty, the environmental degradation that we see every day in less fortunate countries and nuclear weapons and war can only be achieved through enforceable international co-operation and agreement.
In his Sermon on the Mount, Christ declared: "Blessed are the peacekeepers". Today the Canadian forces are among the most blessed people on earth as they prepare to undertake yet another peacekeeping operation, this time in Somalia.
Over the past 45 years more than 85,000 of our young men and women in uniform have participated in each of the peacekeeping operations under the auspices of the United Nations, Canada being the only country in the world to do so. In addition, as the hon. minister said, we have participated in seven non-UN missions.
As an aside, while traditionally our forces stationed in Europe for 40 years were not there as peacekeepers in the traditional sense, they were in reality our front line peacekeepers, unheralded and often questioned over their presence there. They helped preserve peace for 40 years until the iron curtain disintegrated and the Soviet empire vanished.
Today there are more than 2,000 Canadian peacekeepers serving in Cyprus, Syria, the Sinai, Afghanistan, Iraq, Kuwait, the western Sahara, Angola, El Salvador, Cambodia, Yugoslavia and soon Somalia. They also have other ongoing UN commitments in India, Pakistan and the Middle East.
The word peacekeeping does not appear in the United Nations charter. In the previous 45 years the UN has undertaken 25 such missions at the cost of more than 800 lives. In the past three years alone the UN has undertaken 10 new peacekeeping operations. In the previous 32 years it undertook 15; the trend is obvious.
Given world instability, ambitious nationalism, growing tribalism and a seemingly endless supply of weapons in the hands of even the most modest of nations, the likelihood for a coalition of like-minded nations to combine to use force in the interest of peace is growing, not diminishing.
Many of these new missions involve much more than simply placing the UN blue helmets between combatants. In the post-cold war world national sovereignty is no longer considered an absolute. Certainly it will not take priority over the right of the starving and the suffering people in a battle zone to food or medicine, even if there is no cease fire, even if the collapse of
September 16, 1992

government authority makes it impossible to obtain clear consent.
In Cambodia the United Nations will technically run the country until elections can be held in 1993. In Iraq and Kuwait it is mopping up after Operation Desert Storm. In Somalia there is effectively no government. Its job is to ensure that food gets through. In Yugoslavia the job is to keep the peace where there is no peace to keep.
I would like to remind the House and my colleagues that it was in Yugoslavia that a young soldier who happened to be from my riding, Master Corporal Dennis Reid, lost his foot in a land mine and shortly thereafter Sergeant Michael Ralph from St. John's lost his life.

speechtext: I am sorry, but time is running out. The minister spoke for four minutes and the member has spoken for six minutes. I ask for your co-operation, please.

I will wrap up. I appreciate your indulgence.
There are those who say that we are spreading our forces too thin. This is not the time to address that. The important thing for us to do as politicians is ensure that when we are asked to participate in a mission our men and women are properly trained and equipped to undertake it. Otherwise, we should not promise to participate.
I consider it a distinct honour and privilege today to be asked by my party to speak in tribute of Canadian peacekeepers. Peacekeeping and peacemakers are a part of Canadian history of which all Canadians can be very proud. This magnificent monument will serve as a lasting and poignant reminder.

Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the New Democratic Party caucus I would like to welcome the minister's remarks and welcome the dedication of this peacekeeping monument in Ottawa on October 8. Certainly peacekeeping has always been a dimension of Canadian foreign policy and for that matter Canadian defence policy on which there has been a great deal of tripartisan and partisan agreement is something we have all taken a great deal of pride in regardless of our political persuasion.
Routine Proceedings
The minister mentioned in her remarks that over
90,000	Canadian military personnel have served in these missions over the years. It is incredible when you think about how many Canadians have had this experience and the benefits and the insight that experience brings to their participation in Canadian life and the formation of Canadian policy.
I also noticed recently that Canadian peacekeepers are going to be forming an association, analogous to a veterans association and I certainly wish them well in that because I think they could also play a useful role in days to come.
I intended to mention, as the member who spoke before did, how dangerous peacekeeping can be. The member referred to the death of Sergeant Ralph and the injury of Master Corporal Reid. One of the things we might look at in the future would be in some way or another, in the way we have recognized those who have lost their lives in war, to recognize in an individual or collective way those who have lost their lives in the course of peacekeeping. Surely no less than others who lost their lives in various conflicts, these people have put their lives on the line, not only for Canada but for the peace of the world. We should find some way to acknowledge that.
By way of political comment, I want to say two things. As we get more involved in peacekeeping and as we find ourselves sending troops to Somalia and Yugoslavia, we need to find a better mechanism for involving Parliament in those decisions so that we do not get more and more into a kind of executive order regime for the dispensing of Canadian peacekeeping capabilities.
Although I do not disagree with anything the government has done in this respect, there could have been ways to involve Parliament, either by way of some kind of debate or whatever, not to hold things up but to provide an opportunity for Parliament, as a representative of the people, to reflect on just what Canadians are being asked to do.
Finally, as people who have an international reputation as peacekeepers, we have to reflect on our own responsibility to keep the peace here in Canada. God forbid that we who have been involved in all these peacekeeping operations should arrive at a point in our

September 16, 1992
Routine Proceedings
own political future at which we would be faced with walls and we would be faced with conflict and somebody might have to send peacekeepers here. I say that with respect to the possible division of the country which is being advocated by certain people.
To those who are peacekeepers everywhere else, let us keep that in mind and let us do our very best to reconcile differences among ourselves and make sure we are able to keep the peace here at home.
I welcome the announcement and I look forward to being able to look with other Canadians at the monument when it is finally dedicated.

I am pleased to introduce an act respecting airspace over Niagara Falls. This bill is designed to make the airspace over Niagara Falls a restricted zone. It means that helicopters, planes, blimps or any other apparatus wishing to fly in the restricted zone will require a permit from the federal government. This act is to control congestion, noise pollution and to protect the aesthetic qualities of Niagara Falls.
I have had many residents of Niagara Falls recommend the Government of Canada take control of the airspace over Niagara Falls. I agree with them completely. I trust members of all parties will support me in this initiative.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (for the Minister of Finance) moved
speechtext:
that Bill C-80, an act to amend the Income Thx Act, to enact the Children's Special Allowances Act, to amend certain other acts in consequence thereof and to repeal the Family Allowances Act, be read the third time and passed.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak to the members of this House about Bill C-80, legislation which I believe represents a very important step in social policy for families in Canada.
In September 1990 the Prime Minister joined with leaders of over 70 nations to sign a declaration calling for national plans of action on behalf of children. Last December, with the support of all of the provinces, the Prime Minister ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. These were fundamental building blocks for this government's agenda for Canada's children, the Brighter Futures initiatives which the Minister of National Health and Welfare had the great pleasure to announce in May of this year.
Together with the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, there are three major elements of Brighter Futures.
The first element is the proposed child tax benefit which is before us today, a new, simpler approach to children's benefits which provides additional financial support to families with very modest incomes.
The second element is a long-term action plan for Canadian children, describing where we are today and outlining the challenges that the future holds.
The third element is a child development initiative designed to address the conditions that place some Canadian children at risk, especially in their early years. This is a multi-faceted program supported by a five-year allocation of $500 million and ongoing funding after that of $170 million annually.



I believe, -and I am sure all members will agree- that we build the future daily through our children. We are aware of the pressures on parents, and the government believes it is important to support them.

This was one of the underlying principles in developing the proposed child tax benefit program. It increases child benefits by $2.1 billion over five years and better directs benefits according to need. Furthermore-and this is something I intend to come back to because I think its real importance has not been fully appreciated the child tax benefit provides innovative support to low income working families.
I do not think that it is necessary at this point to reiterate the details of the proposed new child tax benefit. However, I do think it would be valuable to look, at least briefly, at the shortcomings of the current system and how this child tax benefit will overcome them.
First, the existing system provides inadequate support to lower income families, especially low income working families. Under the child tax benefit, families with incomes below $50,000 will receive an additional $250 a year in child benefits on average. Moreover, low income working families will receive up to $500 a year in additional benefits through the new earned income supplement.
Second, even though the present system directs more benefits to low income families than to high income families, more can be done to better direct child benefits where they are most needed. There are two aspects of this particular problem.
First, family allowances are directed on the basis of individual income instead of family income. As a result, families with similar total incomes may receive different levels of child benefits. There is no question that family income is a more equitable basis for directing assistance to children.
Second, high income families continue to receive child benefits even though they have relatively little need. I
Government Orders
have been told many times in my constituency by a myriad of people: "For heaven's sake, do not send me these these family allowances cheques, we do not need them in our family. Redirect them where they are most needed". We believe it is more responsible to target benefits to low and modest income families than to continue to make payments to all families.
The child tax benefit will be based on family income. Accordingly, it will be more effectively directed on the basis of need. It will better target assistance to low and modest income families by enriching over-all benefits and redirecting existing benefits from wealthy families to more modest income families.
Delays in the deliveiy of child benefits under the current system has also been identified as a current problem. I remember, for a considerable amount of time, debating in this House both when we were discussing income tax matters and during Question Period, individuals who had to, in order to get their child tax credit, go to tax discounters to get their money immediately. This was causing great problems for some families. The refundable child tax credit, which I am talking about now, represents more than half of a family's federal child benefit. However, it often fails to meet the needs of the child as they occur. They have to assess the tax returns before they can pay the credit.
This delay can be difficult for many families. They have to pay for the children's needs as they arise, but have to wait for more than a year to receive a full credit.
Delays in the delivery of benefits have forced low income families, as I have mentioned, to resort to the tax discounters for earlier payments of their benefits. Tkx discounter's fees average about $80, which represents a substantial amount of money for a low income family.
The child tax benefit, with up-front monthly payments, will provide assistance as it is needed to help with the care of children. Two million families with incomes below $50,000 will receive higher monthly payments and I am very pleased to say that low income families will no longer have to resort to the tax discounters.

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
Finally, the changes to child benefits over the years have gradually led to the present inconvenient patchwork system. Benefits are now delivered to families in different ways and with differing eligibility criteria. For example, family allowances are based on individual income, while the refundable child tax credit is based on family income. In addition, many higher income families question the cumbersome process of receiving family allowances only to have them taxed back at year's end.
The child tax benefit will simplify the current system. How often have members had people in their constituencies say: "For heaven's sake, try to simplify that tax form". This will do it. As I mentioned, three sets of eligibility criteria and delivery systems will be replaced by one benefit delivered in tax-free monthly payments. The new benefit will be calculated automatically for parents. The tax return will be shorter and simpler and high income parents will no longer have to repay benefits at year's end and figure out on the tax form what they owe.
I think we all agree that while the current child benefit system has much to recommend it, a number of problems have crept in over the years and it is time for a fundamental improvement. Too often we in Parliament create programs and let them run ad infinitum without taking a look to see if in fact they are truly effective, if they are doing the job that we intended them to do, or should they be changed. It is time for this major change to come because a number of problems have crepted in over the years and the child tax benefit is that fundamental improvement which we are debating today at third reading.
I want to take a few minutes now to address some of the myths which have developed during the debate and the discussion of the child tax benefit. I read with some dismay some of the headlines in the papers and some of the stories that give part of the story but not the entire story. Today, with my colleagues' permission, I would like to present some facts as they stand to dispel some of these myths.
Some critics have suggested or hinted that the child tax benefit is cutting back on our assistance to children. There is some vague suggestion that benefits for most families are reduced or eliminated in order to provide credits to a few working families. This is absolutely wrong. The child tax benefit will increase assistance for
our children by $2.1 billion. That is with a b and a lot of zeros behind.
While the new benefit is better targeted, 3.1 million families in Canada will receive benefits. That is 85 per cent of all families in Canada with children. Furthermore, all families with incomes below $50,000 will receive either increased benefits or the same level of benefits as under current programs. On average, these families will receive an additional $250 a year in child benefits. It is absolutely clear that this new program is a major enrichment of child benefits for Canadian families.
My colleague over there smiles when I talk about $2.1 billion. I want to emphasize again that it is new money. We talk about old money and new money around here. I am not quite sure that the people who watch us on television are quite sure what we are talking about but they know it is their money and their tax dollars that we are talking about. However, this is new money being injected into this program to help the children of Canada. The increase will be over and above the benefits that would be provided if the current programs were to remain in place. Furthermore, as it has done with the child tax credit, the government is committed to reviewing the level of payments over time and to increase them as fiscal conditions permit.
I would like to remind hon. members that this government has a strong record of increasing child benefits. It is one that I am very proud of and I will stand up on any platform on this country and talk about it. Since 1985 this government has increased the refundable child tax credit four times. We have also introduced a supplement of $213 for children under seven where child care expenses are not claimed. These enrichments have ensured that the average level of federal child benefits paid to low income families has more than kept up with inflation.
Another myth I am hearing is that the child tax benefit leaves social assistance recipients worse off. As a matter of fact, I spoke to a young woman yesterday at the Owen Sound campus of Georgian College. She is a single parent who is receiving social assistance and is back at Georgian College taking courses and trying to get herself off the social assistance roll and back into the work force. She had heard the rumour that because she was receiving social assistance that this new system was going to make her worse off. The suggestion is false. I explained



to her that social assistance recipients will be better off under the child tax benefit in three very important ways.
First, since their child benefits will be consolidated and paid on a monthly basis, families on social assistance will see their monthly payments increase from $35 per child to at least $85 starting January 1993.
Second, those families on social assistance with three or more children and more than $3,750 in earnings will also receive extra benefits.

Third, welfare recipients will no longer have to resort to tax discounters to receive their benefits in advance. They will no longer have to wait a whole year to get all their child benefits, as was the case under the present system. These long waits will now be history.

Also important is the fact that the Minister of National Health and Welfare has met with his provincial counterparts and has urged them to ensure that no social assistance recipients are worse off as a result of the new child tax benefit program. All governments recognize the importance of providing for children. All the provincial governments together with the federal government, as I mentioned earlier, signed the United Nations agreement for children. I am confident that the provinces will not take any action which might be harmful to social assistance recipients. [DOT]
Some people have erroneously viewed the earned income supplement as unfair by providing benefits to those in low wage jobs that are unavailable to those on social assistance. Low income workers often support their families while receiving thousands of dollars less in total government assistance than families on social assistance. How many times have you heard that it is more beneficial for people to be on social assistance than to be out working. They can get more money that way. There is no incentive really to get them off the social welfare roll and into the work force.
Government Orders
In fact families now moving from social assistance to the work force in many instances end up worse off because of employment related expenses and of course the loss of the social assistance.
That is why we brought in the earned income supplement because that helps offset some of these losses that are incurred on moving from social assistance into the work force. By helping these low income working families that often fall through the cracks of existing social programs, this earned income supplement is a first step. I do not say it is the only answer and I admit that. It is not the entire answer but it is the first step in dismantling the welfare trap that so many people find themselves in.
There has also been some suggestion that the new benefit system will not respond to sudden or unexpected changes in family needs as well as the current system does. First let me say that other government programs, such as unemployment insurance and provincial social assistance, respond immediately to changes in family income which occur during a year.
The fact is that the proposed child tax benefit is more responsive than the current system. This is again another advantage for these changes. For example, with the new monthly child tax benefit, payments will respond immediately to the birth of a child, a change in custody and a permanent drop in family income due marriage breakdown or the death of a spouse.
I would like to remind hon. members that in spite of these misunderstandings about the child tax benefit there has been support for it. There has been very good support. There are a lot of questions about it out there, but when those questions are answered, the support is there. I am finding that people are generally supporting these changes because they like to see governments assess programs, streamline them and bring them into the modem day. It makes it more of a rifle approach than a shotgun approach to these benefits.
Some witnesses before the legislative committee pointed out advantages to the new system. First, it is fair since it is based on family income as opposed to individual income. Second, the earned income supplement is a significant advance in social policy. Third, consolidating three benefits into one makes it a simpler system.

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
Fourth, it concentrates benefits on low and modest-income families.
Over all what we are looking at today is a better child benefit system because of those advantages and also because it will provide benefits on a timely basis and the assistance will be more on target. It also enriches the child benefit system by $2.1 billion over five years with 80 per cent of this new money going to families with incomes below $40,000.
As members know, the proposed date of implementation is January 1, 1993, which is just a few months away. It does not seem possible that 1993 is just a few months away. In the interim, as I am sure you can appreciate, Mr. Speaker, we must prepare for the substantial task of switching over to the new program. We must also ensure that Canadians know what the new child tax benefit entails for them. To that end we will need the co-operation of my colleagues on all sides of this House.
In closing, I am confident that this is a program which will benefit Canadian families with children. It is a program which will be supported by Canadians. Over the past several years, Canadians have indicated that they are increasingly in favour of targeting social spending and they have clearly stated that increased family income supplementation is one of the most important social policy issues facing the government.
This program will put money where it is needed most, which is in the hands of families to support them in caring for their children.
The new child tax benefit is one of the four key elements of the Brighter Futures initiative for children. It represents new resources delivered in a new way to meet the changing conditions of Canada and Canadian families. It is a significant investment in the future, our children, their parents and our country. I recommend this bill to all in this House.

Mr. Speaker, before I begin my remarks let me through you express to the minister first my appreciation for the help given by his officials at any time they are asked by the opposition. The briefings provided to us are greatly appreciated.
Second, we appreciate his participation in this debate in which he has again clearly outlined a reasoned
response to the criticisms made on this side of the House. Although we share different perspectives, we certainly share the same purpose of doing more for children in this country.
I would like to use this opportunity to summarize the criticisms made by this caucus on this piece of legislation. This has been a hastily held debate and in many cases many members in the national Liberal caucus have not had an opportunity to speak. The list of speakers is long and many people have expressed concern about not being able to speak.
On behalf of the House, I would again like to register my complaint to the government for not allowing a full debate. Though it has a deadline it would like to meet, Canadians have an objective to make sure children are helped in the best possible way. We are not at all convinced that the use of time allocation at each stage of the debate was of any help to Canadians in understanding the fundamental changes taking place.
As is so often the case when one is faced with a major debate and a major shift in public policy, one goes back to the roots in trying to understand what it is that has been attempted in the past and where we should be going from here.
As you well know, the Liberal Party of Canada is very proud of its tradition in social policy that began in the 1930s and carried right through almost uninterrupted to 1984. There were several stages of progressive legislation that did more and more for the average Canadian.
I would like to speak of the late and wonderful Senator Croll. He used to admonish us in caucus by saying: "Never forget the working man. Never forget why you were elected. Speak out for those who are paying the bills of this country". Surely Senator Croll's last comments in caucus, before he passed away, were exactly along those lines.
As I stand here today I am reminded of the lives given to this countiy by people who felt this commitment.
In many ways, the basis of the modem state for social policy can be traced back to 1943, almost 50 years ago. As the minister said, 1993 is just around the comer. That will mark 50 years since a royal commission was chaired by Professor Leonard Marsh from the University of British Columbia on social security for Canadians and the requirement for post-war planning.
September 16, 1992

It is very interesting that at the very time the Liberal government of Mackenzie King was fighting the Second World War it also had to plan exactly what should be done during the reconstruction period.
Marsh set out the conditions which drove many of the programs that came after the war in the reconstruction. He concluded his royal commission with the following statement that I think should be read into the record and serve as a benchmark as to what we try to do as Canadians to this day. Some things we do have to be reminded of.
He concluded:
Finally, the obvious but vital point must be made that social security payments are not money lost. The social insurances, and even some straightforward disbursements like children's allowances, are investments in morale and health, in greater family stability and from both material and psychological viewpoints, in human productive efficiency. They demand personal and community responsibilities; but in the eyes of most of the people who are beneficiaries, give a more evident meaning to the ideas of common effort and national solidarity. It has yet to be proved that any democracy which underwrites the social minimum for its citizens is any the weaker or less wealthy for doing so.
It was research such as this and thoughtfulness such as this that led to the establishment of universality and the treatment of every Canadian as being equal, whether they became unemployed, sick, or needy. It led to dozens of programs which, I agree with the minister, have become very confusing in some Canadians' minds but nevertheless have fundamental principles that have to be plucked out, defended, and reinforced.
This week is not only a time to think of Senator Croll as we go through changes in social policy but also the Hon. Paul Martin, whose funeral is tomorrow. It will be attended by many people on all sides of this House who have a fond memory of him.
I was reading through his autobiography, A Very Public Life, in which he discussed what it was like to be involved with these programs. His reference point was the Marsh commission:
Marsh called for planning to reconvert industry, to maintain jobs and to retrain the work force. Public employment schemes and a well-financed works program would counteract the expected postwar recession. The report went on to recommend a national health program based on universal health insurance and with levels of assistance that depended on individual income-the Marsh report also recommended both children's allowances and a universal,
Government Orders
contributory old age pension of $45 a month for married couples- as a clear part of the policy of providing a national minimum standard of living.
Mr. Speaker, if you think that we are broke today can you imagine the reaction of a cabinet coming out of the Second World War. I will continue reading what the hon. Paul Martin wrote:
The cost of these changes disturbed some in the cabinet, including C. D. Howe and the conscientious keeper of the public purse, Jim Ilsley. Ilsley's objection was that the report, having been released prematurely, did not carry the official sanction of government and therefore could not be accepted as the basis for legislation. While Ilsley might have based his official objections to the proposals on these grounds, I knew that philosophically he did not favour spending the government's money in this manner. One night he and I talked long into the wee hours arguing the pros and cons of state measures for social security. He honestly felt that the government could not afford these measures and that some of them should be undertaken by the family, the church or the provinces. Ilsley kept asking me: "Why do you want to saddle us with these things?" My answerwas: "Because of my liberalism".
That is the benchmark from that side of the House to this side of the House. Governments are always without money. Governments are always concerned about deficits. We share those concerns. It is also the responsibility of governments, one generation after another, to move ahead and provide for a more secure society.
Last night I was watching television and there was a discussion about rising crime rates in the Ottawa region. An academic from the University of Ottawa was on. He said: "What do you expect? You have done absolutely everything possible on the public side to increase crime rates. Why are you surprised? If people do not think you care about them, as a government, why should they care about their neighbours, why should they care about their communities? Why should they not be crime ridden? What is there in the way you are treating them that would cause them in return to feel part of a state system that was looking after them?"
The situation is obviously more complicated than that but within those words he had the truth of our responsibility as a government to people in our society. From the time of Paul Martin in the mid-forties straight through to 1984 there was a series of measures that reinforced universality and reinforced the commitment of the national government to all regions of the country whether they be individuals or families and whether they be young or old. I count among the accomplishments of

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
these years the Canada Assistance Plan, regional development and medicare.
Since 1984 there have been a number of measures that have begun to achieve just the opposite effect and have undermined the foundations that we set out to put together in this country. There are many examples, but I include here as highlights of these measures: Bills C-20, C-32 and C-69.
During his remarks the minister looked at me when I had a bemused look on my face as he was talking about the accomplishment of finding $2.1 billion in the system. What he failed to mention in the course of those remarks was that the government had taken $3.5 billion out of the system previous to that. As responsible politicians and members of Parliament we must take that $2.1 billion into account.
However, it is obvious to everyone that the undermining of the system has been so fundamental and I would say -I do not use this word frivolously -terrorizing to people that they need to see the government make a greater and greater commitment to the children.
We come now, after these negative changes in the system of Canada from 1984 to 1991-92, to the budget of 1992 in which the government presented us with Bill C-80, an act to amend the family allowances and related legislation dealing with payments to children.
Our caucus has opposed this at every opportunity it has had, which as I mentioned has not been very many. The purpose of this legislation is to move away from the concept of universality and look at the children of the country with a more targeted approach. The defence of this has been at various times: "The poorest of the poor are now looked after and that there is sufficient support now for middle income families that the payments will look after their children better than they were before".
As the minister has pointed out, there has been some cutting of comers in this debate and I would suggest to him that the cutting of comers has been as much on the government's side as on the opposition side. The gains, where they are, are minimal. Most families earning between $30,000 to $50,000 a year will make perhaps as little as $4 a month more for their children.
At first the sums will appear to be very generous because of the wide-ranging tax changes not fully understood by Canadians. Many families do not realize the impact of reporting family income, and I agree with the government that this is a fair system. The impact of changing the reporting of income from as an individual to as a family and the fact that the average Canadian income is slightly less than $53,000 means that many people will receive fewer benefits than they are anticipating.
In other words, the defence of the legislation is that the poorest of the poor will be better off, but the government has not yet explained how the absence of increases for social assistance families will in any way help the poorest of the poor.
Second, by defining families between $30,000 and $50,000 as being not in need of much extra money how does the government explain, particularly to families in urban Canada, how they should be able to look after their children just fine in these economic times, leaving aside the more than 30 tax increases that have taken place since this government was formed?
The average Canadian in this income level has been taxed again and again and again in small ways and big ways. Suddenly, at the end of this whole taxation process they are offered an extra $4 a month for their family, and the government describes this as a major step forward.
I beg to differ and I think that the average Canadian family would beg to differ that they will see major improvements in their way.
I would like to go into more detail about our criticisms on two fronts. First, I would like to deal with process. Today we finish up the debate in third reading in the House under time allocation. The government has done all it can to fast-track the bill and limit public debate.
Bill C-80 was debated for the first time on June 1. The government forced a closure motion on the bill on the second day of debate on June 9. The bill was then referred to a legislative committee under the Finance envelope. Few witnesses were able to appear due to time constraints imposed by government members.
Of the witnesses who did appear, all but one presenter, a junior academic brought in from British Columbia, expressed serious concerns over the many shortcomings
September 16, 1992
