of the bill. Most witnesses were also critical of the process used by the government to try to force the bill through Parliament.
I want to read a letter into the public record that was sent by one of the witnesses, Barbara Blouin from Halifax. She wrote: "The whole experience was most disheartening. I am beginning to understand increasingly that democratic process under the Mulroney government is nothing but a sham, a charade, when virtually all the witnesses called for Bill C-80 criticized it. I had already read about it in The Globe and Mail. Nevertheless the bill was rammed through the committee process by the majority of its Tory members.
There can be no other conclusion than this. They do not listen, they do not respond, they are not answerable to the people. They will do what they want because they have the power to do so.
I have not felt so powerless in all my life. To actually have an opportunity to speak to some of Canada's leaders, to have worked very hard to write a brief and then to realize that it meant nothing and even that I and others were being used to uphold the propaganda that this is a democratic process, is hard to swallow".
This is a very severe criticism. I must tell the House that it is from someone I only met at the committee and I have no idea of her background or whether she is involved with politics or not. It is simply that she is a very serious researcher.
In the meantime, the government is busy on its so-called communications strategy. The minister alluded to the fact it was to make Canadians more aware. One of my associates in Manitoba wrote to me. He has a letter that he received from a F. D. Kealey, program manager, child tax benefit, dated August 27 so he received it before the House came back.
"Dear respondent, due to a very high response we have not yet processed all the coupons we have received for information on the proposed child tax benefit. In the meantime, please find enclosed two brochures which will give you some background on these issues".
The interesting thing is that this friend never sent in a coupon. This letter came to his law office and he has no children under the age of 21.
Government Orders
We should ask ourselves: "What is the mailing list? What are you doing? How much money do you have to waste? Did you write to every lawyer in the country, every law firm? Did you write to every business on Broadway Avenue in Winnipeg? What is it that you have to communicate seriously when you use form letters, mail that has no relationship to the people receiving it". It also has nothing to do with the child benefits program but in fact Brighter Futures which is another propaganda program.
The government may argue its need to communicate but it must do it more honestly, with less waste of government funds and more directly to the point of what the real, modest benefits to any family will be under this program.
I do hope the House leaders for the government will instruct the leaders of the Senate to have full and open hearings and that the January 1 deadline is manufactured. We learned through the constitutional process that manufactured deadlines are deadly. There is nothing magical about January 1. People want a real program and they want their money spent wisely.
All those witnesses which had no opportunity to appear before the House of Commons committee should be given every opportunity to appear before the Senate committee.
In addition to objections about process, we have several objections to the substance of this legislation. I would like to outline them quickly.
First, assistance to the poorest families, namely those on social assistance, will not increase.
Second, the partial deindexation of a benefit and complete lack of indexation of the threshold amounts will result in the gradual erosion of the benefit amount as well as lessen the number of families eligible for the benefit. This is a crucial fact. The 3 per cent solution this government has stuck into the legislation and after defeating the motions moved yesterday, means an erosion of up to 30 per cent in the next decade. With the threshold not being properly indexed, people will also lose real income opportunities.
Third, the lack of a proper mechanism to ensure that dramatic changes in family income are reflected in the monthly benefit amount. As it now stands, it could take up to 18 months for the benefit to be adjusted.

Government Orders
Fourth, the lack of a federal-provincial arrangement could result in the provinces capping welfare payments.
Fifth, the estimated $2.1 billion increase over five years to the child benefits system must be measured against the $3.5 billion already taken out of the child benefit system between 1986 and 1991. On that point, several witnesses were incensed about the reality of how little new money was actually going to be put into this program. When I was willing to concede with a couple of witnesses that perhaps the government's $2.1 million was the correct figure, they were even willing to challenge me on that and in fact presented documents to the committee that were ignored by the government members showing that the $2.1 million figure was not real.
The long-awaited and promised child care strategy, which is a significant deterrent to child poverty, has been completely abandoned, creating additional financial hardship on low and middle income families, especially single parent families.
In addition, this government has brought forward several initiatives which negatively affect poor families, such as cutbacks in funding for social housing, the cancellation of funding for co-op housing, the cap on the Canadian Assistance Plan and changes to UI. There has been no increase in the federal minimum wage since 1986, one of the fundamentals for guaranteeing family income.
The bill signifies the end of universality and the recognition of the higher expenses parents incur. Some women in abusive relationships will lose their only form of income, however modest it is, the family allowance. This was mentioned explicitly by witnesses, including a woman from New Brunswick who was very eloquent on the need to protect women in abusive relationships by giving them at least a monthly allowance.
There was lack of consultation both before and after the release of the white paper. The Conservative government is trying to drive this legislation through Parliament totally unamended. As a matter of fact the Minister of National Health and Welfare, with the exception of his brief intervention yesterday, did not appear before the committee to defend this proposal which supports a disturbing trend by the Conservative government of transferring social policy to the financial envelope.
The question we have is: who is making social policy for this government? Is it the Finance department or is it the health and welfare department?
I go back to the commentary of Paul Martin, remembering his life, when he said that it is the role of the Minister of National Health and Welfare to promote the need of the average person. It was the role of the Minister of Finance to protect the public budget. That was a necessary and natural conflict in a cabinet, but you do not blend the two roles together because you need an advocate for people.
During this whole debate, the silence of the Minister of National Health and Welfare, who is supposed to be an advocate on behalf of people in need, is absolutely amazing. The government is treating this bill as one of its major initiatives, yet we have not heard from the department which is most responsible for seeing it through.
There is also the regressive nature of the increased child care deduction. In the same bill there is the emergence of the RRSP tax deduction which will cost the government millions in unclaimed revenue and could be of assistance to people in need for programs such as this.
We also have other problems. It is not only ourselves who have raised these concerns, but people as diverse as Ken Battle from the Caledon Institute of Social Policy, a representative from the End Legislated Poverty group, the Minister of Social Services from British Columbia, Professor Shelley Phipps from Dalhousie University, the Citizens for Public Justice, the Social Planning Council of Metropolitan Toronto and the Child Poverty Action group, Lise Corbeil from National Anti-Poverty Organization, Trevor Williams from the Family Services Canada, Michael Goldberg from the Social Planning and Research Council of British Columbia, Terrence Huns-ley from Queen's University, Martha Friendly from the National Action Committee on the Status of Women, Dr. Robert Glossop from the Vanier Institute of the Family, Richard Shillington, co-author of The Canadian Fact Book on Poverty, Marcelle Dolment a Reseau d'action et information pour les femmes and Patrick Johnson from the Canadian Council on Social Development. These are some of the witnesses who came forward and consistently pointed out the problems of this legislation and this

government, in return, consistently refused to acknowledge them.
Earlier this year Queen's University hosted a conference in its public policy forum on the February 1992 budget at the John Deutsch Institute for the Study of Economic Policy. I would like to thank the member for Kingston and the Islands who mentioned this report in the House in the middle of the debate on the report stage and asked me to bring it to the attention of the House in more detail.
During that conference Martin Browning of McMaster University presented a paper on the child benefit package. He asked the question: "Do the new proposals move us significantly closer to the goal of eliminating child poverty?" His answer: "The above analysis suggests not; indeed, taking into account the fact that the benefits are only partially indexed, it is probable that unless there is some new initiative in the next eight years, poverty among families with children will be even higher in the year 2000".
This government is not only presenting us with a new initiative, but in fact it is presenting us with the foundations of worse conditions in the future.
Mr. Browning also addressed directly the question of the earned income supplement. Again he asked the question: "What, then, are the likely incentive effects? First, I am sceptical that most unemployment is a matter of choice so that policies that make full pay work even more attractive are likely to lead to increased frustration rather than higher participation rates. In knowing this, my guess is that the new EIS will not make much difference".
There is one academic interpretation of the much touted $500 earned income supplement in this program.
As a result of our criticism of this program, the Liberal caucus introduced four amendments earlier this week as part of our package of 72 ways that the government could have changed this legislation and made it better. We first asked for the deletion of the entire bill. Second, we asked for the full indexation of the benefit and of the threshold amounts.
The government should always remember what happened in the fight with the pensioners when they tried to index the pensions, with the famous scene on television
Government Orders
across this country of the pensioner from Montreal saying "Goodbye, Charlie Brown". If the children of this country could have the same understanding of their rights and of the obligations of this government as the elderly have, we would see a children's crusade coming into this Chamber saying, "Do you not understand how fundamentally you are moving away from a program of helping all children?"
Children do not make the distinction as to whether they are rich or poor, or whether their dad is working or their mum is working; children only know whether or not people care for them. When legislation is passed saying that we in this House only have to care about certain types of children because the family will look after the rest, or the church will look after the rest, or the province will look after them, or somebody will feed them at the schools, as soon as that is said as a principle, as soon as that is recognized, as soon as it is stated in public that some people who are two years old should be able to look after themselves because their mum or dad makes a lot of money, then there is a fundamental misunderstanding of what happens in family life in this country.
I think this government is going to pay a price for that.
I know that I cannot wait to stand up on any platform with anybody from this government who thinks that you can make the distinction between rich kids and ordinary kids, and say: "You have to look after yourself as soon as you are bom and if your family makes a mistake, so be it, we are not concerned".
Once you move away from the principle of universality it does not matter where the lines are. It does not matter where the margins are at first. It does not matter whether you are looking after 85 per cent at first. The point is that you have made a decision that 15 per cent does not count. Therefore, someone else like your buddies in the Reform Party can come along and say: "It should not be 15 per cent, maybe it should be 30 per cent", and someone else says: "Maybe it should be 35 per cent" and then someone else in 10 years says: "Maybe we cannot help any of them because we do not have any money".
What happens when you go home to your family and you say: "I am really sorry we do not have enough money; we are going to skip on the kids this month". Can you imagine a conversation like that? That is what this government has just said through the minister: "We do

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
not have the money; we are going to skip on 15 per cent of the kids next month". Nice.
Will the next Minister of Finance stand up and say that he is going to skip on 30 per cent? You did not mind the first 15 per cent? Do you mind the next 15 per cent?
That is why this party has fought this measure every single step of the way. We will continue the struggle in the Senate and we will make sure that Canadians understand that the principle behind this legislation is terrible, is destructive and is contrary to every principle of fairness that we have here.
We also asked in our third amendment for the inclusion of a mechanism, possibly a child benefits adjustment board, to deal with a responsiveness problem. As the bill now stands, if you have a significant loss of income, it can be up to 18 months before the government will change the amount of money you receive for your children.
I used the example earlier in debate which I think is a worth-while one. It is entirely possible in some of our industries for an engineer in the petrochemical industry earning $70,000 a year, for example, to be part of a wide spread lay-off of 2,000 or 3,000 people, which is happening in Calgary, and find himself on UI receiving $22,000 and then on to social assistance. It is not until July of the next year that he can pick up money for his children.
In the meantime, instead of making it available for, say, three children, $273 a month which they parade out here as being so responsive and so fundamental, that which would provide food for these children, they turn around and say: "It is too difficult to make these adjustments. This is so flexible already. We cannot possibly consider this".
If you are serious about poverty, you must know the literature on poverty. You must know the reality is thousands and thousands of people pass through temporary poverty. It is at that moment in which their family is facing a crisis that you have to help. It is not 18 months later. Most families come and go in this cycle. We are in a terrible terrible cycle in this recession and it is time we designed programs and helped people adjust to it.
The Minister for International Trade totally denies the reality that he has no adjustment programs, the government has no adjustment programs, for free trade. On
social policy they are committing the same error. There are no adjustment policies for people who need help when they get laid off and when they have to provide food.
Your mortgage payments do not stop for 18 months. You still have to maintain a house. There are stories, for example, in Calgary of people having to re mortgage their house upward to get cash to buy food for their children. Yet this government says under this new program it can provide lots of cash for families in need. That is substantially wrong. The way the government designed this legislation it should be embarrassed for ( a) introducing it (b) not amending it and (c) standing up here at third reading and denying it. It is not responsive and for that reason alone it should be defeated.
Last, we are very anxious that this government in a more public fashion commit the provinces to not changing the levels of social assistance if this program is enhanced. Several speakers have stood up and shared the view that with the new monthly payments many social assistance families in poorer provinces are going to be made vulnerable as to what their total income is, based on these calculations.
We have been assured privately and informally by the ministers of the Crown that this is nothing to worry about. They have assurances from the provinces. Put it in writing. Make sure we have agreements on this new program to ensure that nobody will be hurt from social assistance.
There are thousands and thousands of Canadians who never thought before they would be on social assistance. It is a very tough life. It is a very cruel relationship with government. Do not make it any worse by people sitting there and staring at you and saying I know you have more money. You have this child benefits package and let us take a look at your total income package. Those who know the social assistance program understand this very clearly.
By way of conclusion, I would like to draw the attention of the House to a former Canadian still proud of being a Canadian originally, John Kenneth Galbraith, who in his Culture of Contentment wants us to understand just how dangerous this situation is across North America.
September 16, 1992

Let me read a couple of paragraphs: "The present and devastated position of the socially assisted under-class has been identified as the most serious social problem of the time as it is also the greatest threat to long run peace and civility. Life in the great cities in general could be improved and only will be improved by public action, by better schools with better paid teachers, by strong well financed welfare services, by counselling on drug addiction, by employment training, by public investment in the housing that no industrial country has provided for the poor, by private enterprise, by adequately supporting health care recreation facilities, libraries and police. The question once again, much accommodating rhetoric to the contrary is not what can be done but what will be paid".
Although Mr. Galbraith is writing more directly about the United States, his comments apply to this country and we wait and we wait at great risk.
It is not just one program. A whole number of things have to be set in motion again. If this government does not understand it, it will be replaced by a government that does.
On a very final note, there is a relationship between what we do for children and the Constitution. In the rhetoric associated with the Constitution and this Charlottetown agreement, there is a social and economic union. The Constitution would contain a statement of key social and economic policy objectives shared by all the governments in the federation.
The social policy objectives would include comprehensive, universal, portable, accessible, publicly administered health care, adequate social services and benefits, education, and so forth. I want to stop there.
Adequate social services and benefits: Does this legislation stand the test of being the first piece of legislation introduced in the country under the new Constitution? Is it adequate? Does it provide for the well-being of all Canadians? Does it provide for the well-being of all families? Does it provide for the well-being of all children?
By the very tests that this government has agreed to in this accord, the first step forward is maintenance, contrary to all the principles that it has been boasting about. I would suggest to the government in good will that this
Government Orders
piece of legislation be removed, that this House recommit itself to fighting child poverty by the year 2000, our original recommendation and agreed upon by all parties of the House two years ago, that we stake out the turf and honestly admit to each other that this is not sufficient, that we begin again and produce a better piece of legislation for all of Canada's children.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: As indicated in the Order Paper, the first two speakers have 40 minutes maximum. There are no questions or comments. There are after the third speaker.

Mr. Speaker, there has been a lot of discussion in our country lately on family values and family issues.
The right wing in this country has attempted to hijack the word family and give it an elitist and twisted definition. New Democrats do not try to exclude people from the definition of family. Families come in all shapes and sizes. People will always define their own family groupings: Dual career families, what is considered by some the traditional family with a male breadwinner and a mother at home, single-parent families, same sex couples with or without children, or middle-aged people looking after elderly parents.
Who is to declare that a middle-aged woman or man caring for aging parents cannot define themselves as a family? The Conservatives have a family caucus which believes that the family is deteriorating, and they set themselves up as the judge of Canadian families.
They want to decide who is in a family and who is not, who is deserving of family benefits and who is not. This so-called family caucus is made up of mainly middle-aged men and, not surprisingly, the idea of family that they have come up with fits them exactly.
I will quote a family caucus member, the hon. member for Mississauga South. This is a direct quote:
It-
Meaning all federal legislation.
-should define a family as a male and a female living together to raise
children and that is the only kind of family that ought to be defined.
Therefore, widows with children, orphans, children of divorced parents, children who live with parents of the same sex, these children according to that family caucus model are to be excluded from family benefits and have no rights to family services under Canadian law.

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
This is a horrifying and unacceptable view of Canadian families. Canadians in fact will be shocked to know that we have our own Dan Quayle in Parliament. They have elected people who do not understand what Canadian families are about today and who want to reach into a past that in fact never really existed.
The proportion of single-parent families has not risen significantly over the last 50 years although the cause of single parenthood has changed. In the past widowhood, primarily after each war, was the primary cause of single parenthood. Today it is divorce. Thirteen per cent of Canadian families are single parent families. A happy life for children with one parent can often be better than an unhappy or an abused life with two parents.
One in ten Canadian families is headed by a common law couple. Sixty-two per cent of all husband and wife families are dual earner families. In fact, only a minority of Canadian families are comprised of a husband breadwinner, wife at home, and children.
These families deserve to be protected, but so do other families. A discussion of the family caucus is, in fact, very relevant here because its chair has taken credit for the bill that we are discussing today, the elimination of the family allowance.
I want to point out how anti-family that family caucus is, and how it is made up mainly of people who are catering to their own special interest group. Although I will be talking about family policy, I also want to remind members of this House that 23 per cent of all households in Canada are made up of people who live alone, and they are important too.
NDP policy on families is geared to helping all families survive economically and emotionally. It involves measures to fight poverty. One in six Canadian children is living in poverty, while government policies on social assistance and child support exacerbate the situation.
For example, the bill before us today, Bill C-80, eliminates the universality of family allowance. This bill will give family benefits only to the eligible poor. It will set up two classes of poor. This bill is an attempt by this government to identify the deserving poor and the undeserving poor, and in fact is a back to the future kind of bill, back to the Victorian times when people were classed according to whether they were deserving of help or not deserving of help.
The new family benefit will give more money to those already earning an income in the paid work force than it will give to families in which the adults have been laid off during this recession, whose jobs have disappeared because of the trade deal, and who are not trained for any industry where there are jobs available now; people who are having problems finding a job with an unemployment rate in this country of 11 per cent; homemakers who are finding it necessary but difficult to reintegrate themselves into the paid work force; all of those who are on unemployment insurance, social assistance or are receiving no help at all.
The people who are made to suffer the most through this bill are the children in those families. The children who need the money most will get less of it. The children who are going to school hungry and relying on food banks will get less money for food and clothing than children of those parents who are in the paid work force.
The government is saying that some children deserve food and clothing more than other children. I think that is a horrible legacy of poverty and disrespect to put on to the backs of children.
Children who go to school hungry do less well at school. They are hyperactive and they cannot concentrate. There are long-term physical, emotional and intellectual consequences to growing up without adequate nutrition. These problems start in pregnancy with poor women who do not have enough nutritious food. When one child suffers from poverty and abuse, all of society suffers in the long run with a work force that is uneducated and ill-equipped for the types of employment available, with health problems and with an increase in crime.
Child poverty and abuse is a problem for all Canadians, and this bill does nothing to solve it. In fact, it may even exacerbate it. Bill C-80 was discredited by almost every witness who came to speak before the committee that examined the bill. One witness to the committee, Professor Phipps, compared Canada's treatment of poor families with that of other countries and he said, and I will quote from his testimony: "Canadian public transfers leave families with poor kids still 15 per cent below the poverty line, whereas in lots of other countries such as Norway, Germany, the U.K., public transfers raise them to at least the poverty line". Actually in Sweden,
September 16, 1992

they were raised to substantially higher than poverty income levels.
Witnesses to the committee pointed out that the proposed child benefits available to low-income families are exactly the same as those available in the current system. They are just juggled about so that it appears that one is getting more in the mail but one also pays more in taxes. What is eliminated is the family allowance which had been given to everyone regardless of family income. If the family income was high, the family allowance was taxed back. However, at least the family allowance came and it was in mother's name.
In some families, even high income families, this was the only money that some women received in their own name. This is particularly important to the women who are battered both physically and emotionally by the men with whom they live. That income, as small as it was, could make the difference between being able to get out of an abusive relationship and having to endure it because there is nowhere to go and no funds with which to leave.
This proposed child benefit is not indexed to inflation so it is going to be worth less and less and less every year. The bill also enhances the deduction for child care expenses which puts far more money into the hands of upper income families than middle and low income families. In other words, those who are well off get a tax break because of this bill and this tax approach to child care is really ludicrous and ineffective.
We live in a country now where 1.3 million Canadian children need child care because both parents, or their only parent, are in the paid work force. Perhaps they are at university and are studying full time. Licensed care is only available for one quarter of these children.
This government has already limited funding for child care through its spending limits on the Canada Assistance Plan for British Columbia, Ontario and for Alberta. If the federal government was serious about child care it would have brought in a national child care program which it has been promising, promising and promising for almost a decade now. Tax measures do not create child care spaces.
Government Orders
Contrary to the twisted justifications of the family caucus of the Conservative party, this bill provides no choice to parents in terms of raising their children. The benefit is so little that it does not allow women or men to stay home to raise the kids. It cuts off all help to middle-income women who do wish to be full-time homemakers. It does not create the necessary child care spaces for those who wish to use child care outside the home.
There is no choice in this bill for parents or for Canadians who, despite the protestations against the bill, are being forced to swallow bad legislation. The bill proposes a complex child benefit system to replace what was the simple and straightforward family allowance program. Under this new system, parents must almost be accountants to figure out how much the government owes them. It increases the likelihood that mistakes and underpayments will go unnoticed.
The proposed benefit means more bureaucracy because each individual family will have to be looked at every year in order to determine its eligibility. More bureaucrats will be hired to deal with this at a time when this government talks on and on and on about downsizing government. It increases the chances of delays in getting cheques because it is individualized and not automatic.
The child benefit does not even come close to the actual cost of raising a child and it is about time that the government recognized how much Canadian families are subsidizing tax breaks to profit making corporations through their own personal taxes. Canadian families are overtaxed and the work of mothers in raising children is neither respected nor recognized.
The family allowance was a recognition of the contribution that all Canadian parents make to Canadian society by raising children. That recognition will now be gone. It is replaced by a benefit which amounts to an ever decreasing scrap to the poor. A witness from the social planning council of metro Toronto pointed out that evidence from European countries shows that the countries with universal programs have the lowest child poverty rate. Services and benefits directed to the poor become poorer programs because the middle class no longer sees itself as having a stake in the program and in defending it. How long will middle income earners

Government Orders
continue to pay taxes to support benefits which they will no longer receive?
The Conservative government has invoked closure on this bill to eliminate the family allowance which means that it has undemocratically limited debate on it. This is in order to pass it as soon as possible and according to its own agenda and not that of the Canadian people.
This bill is a major shift in Canadian social policy. It is an Americanization, if you will, of Canadian social policy. The Tories wanted to pass it in one day but we did not co-operate and we have stretched out the debate as long as possible to give groups and concerned Canadians an opportunity to talk sense to this government.
Another shift is that social polity has been commandeered now by the Department of Finance which obviously does not understand anything about children or their needs. Social policy should be developed in consultation with Canadians and community groups and be handled by those with a deep understanding and commitment to the well-being of children and Canadian families.
Thanks to successive Liberal and Conservative governments, the Canadian record on family and child poverty is dismal. In Canada, 75 per cent of men default on their child support payments. This leaves single parent families with the worst poverty rate of any Canadian family. Of all single mother families, 57 per cent live in poverty and this figure has not changed since 1974. In Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Israel, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Germany there are guaranteed minimum child support payments.
Families need financial and emotional support in order to be strong. New Democrat policies include effective anti-poverty measures such as fair taxation, raising the minimum wage and adequate pensions. Our policy includes family support measures such as child care and parental leave, the valuing of women's work in the home and the valuing of women's work in the paid work force through pay equity and employment equity.
Our policy is to establish a national program of non-profit child care which is accessible, affordable,
flexible, of high quality, culturally sensitive and developed with community input. We believe that aboriginal child care should be run by aboriginal communities.
There are other policies that could be put into place. Maternity and parental leave must be part of a comprehensive child care system. Our parental leave system lags far behind that of most European countries. They have grasped that most workers are also parents and have personal needs as parents. In the short term, parental leave should be extended to 26 weeks. In the long term, we should be aiming for a system of 9 months for paid parental leave. Ten days of paid leave should be available to workers to tend to their family responsibilities.
There are examples in Canada of governments that, even in this recessionary time, have put an emphasis on these kinds of policies. The Ontario New Democratic government has refined its pay equity system and it is now the most advanced in North America. My British Columbia New Democratic colleagues are also introducing pay equity in my province. Pay equity is an important family issue because many women must work outside the home in order to support their families. Unattached older women are more likely than their male counterparts to live in poverty. This situation will continue as long as women are not paid their worth on the job and have less of an opportunity than men to build up a pension in their own name. Employment equity is also necessary to ensure that women and their families are getting a fair deal.
Women do paid work outside the home in 71 per cent of families in which there are children under the age of six. It is an absolute crime that we have no child care program in this country. Policies should include family support services to help families and the individuals who comprise them when faced with problems of abuse, alcoholism or ill health.
What this government is not telling us is that programs to eliminate violence in the family and to heal those who have survived it is an essential part of any family policy. An accessible, high quality health care system is also an
September 16, 1992

essential party of family policy to ensure the health of families and future generations.
All families are deserving of respect and support regardless of race, religion, sexual orientation or class. White, middle class families deserve to be healthy and happy and to have every chance in life as do aboriginal families, black families, mixed families, same sex couple families, poor families and all of the families that make up our country. Human rights protection is an important part of family policy.
We need a Court Challenges Program to ensure that the rights of all Canadians are defined and enforced.
I went on the radio with a family caucus member the other day on CBC to talk about family values. He said that some families should be favoured over others because: "It is a matter of priorities". I agree, family issues are a matter of priorities. His government priorities include spending $4.5 billion on 50 submarine-hunting helicopters, more than $1 billion on a low-level defence system to protect troops in Europe against a Soviet attack now that the Soviet Union no longer exists, $250 million to purchase anti-tank guns and $1 billion in tax breaks to the rich through an expected trust legislation. It goes on and on.
There was a $25 million cut in affordable housing and a $200 million cut in training for workers who need to train for jobs to support their families. Support for families and child care through the Canada Assistance Plan has been cut. There is the scrapping of plans for a national child care program and now the elimination of family allowance. Obviously these people do not have their priorities straight.
Family policy is more than the narrow and restrictive vision that this government presents. It attempts to glorify the family while cutting almost every service that helps our families to stay strong.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am appalled after listening to the opposition members talking in this House for the last couple of days about how dreadful this piece of legislation is. They make it sound as if we are cutting money out of the budget. This
Government Orders
is totally false. There is more money going into families from this piece of legislation than is provided now.
We are consolidating three different programs. We are adding $2.1 billion over the next five years in additional moneys to go into these various programs. We know that over 80 per cent of all families receive these benefits. Eighty per cent of the increase will go to families below the $40,000 mark in their income. All families with incomes below $50,000 have either increased benefits or will be at the same level. On average, families with incomes below $50,000 will receive an additional $250 in benefits.
I have never heard any of the opposition members ever giving out this factual information. I can tell you that the people will have to judge for themselves in the new year when the benefits start going to them when they see just how beneficial this will be for them. It is a simpler form of getting the money to the people who need it. This is not something that we are trying save money from.
The earned income supplement of up to $500 provides extra help to low income working families. This is a group, by the way, that has often fallen between the cracks. The monthly payments are tax free. They no longer have to report this income on their tax returns. I did not hear the hon. member opposite telling people this. She was doing nothing but condemning this.
The tax return in the future will be shorter and simpler because of this very important ingredient that has been put in this. This is money that goes to individuals and they do not have to report it.
I would ask the hon. member opposite if she does not think that this is a benefit for the people of Canada and for the families that we want to target money to.
Ms. Black As I said in my remarks, this legislation is creating two classes of poor. This is not a new and forward looking type of legislation. This is an old Victorian idea of there being the deserving poor and the undeserving poor.
What I said very clearly today is that the children who live in those families should not be penalized because folks on that side of the House figure that the children of the working poor deserve a bit more, but those children

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
whose parents are on assistance or on no kind of government support are not deserving of assistance.
This program is not indexed to the cost of living. It is the beginning of the end because you have broken faith. You have broken faith with the Canadian people on the universality of the family allowance.
The Prime Minister said in 1984 that universal social programs were a sacred trust not to be touched by his government. I would ask the Prime Minister to live up to that pledge he made to the Canadian people and stand up with the members on this side of the House and vote no to Bill C-80.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to comment that I was quite simply appalled, in a sense insulted, by the attempt of the hon. member from the New Democratic Party who tried to mischaracterize in her opening remarks the family caucus in our party.
I want to make a few comments about the family caucus, how it is composed and how it works. In the House we do not usually hear or speak about the workings of caucus. It is very important for all members and the public to understand that this is not a group in any way designing against the interests of families.
The members of this caucus committee consist of men and women, individual members of Parliament, mothers, wives, grandmothers, single mothers, widows, men who are fathers and husbands, divorced parents, widowers and single parents; people with complex personal interest in families, who sit together at a table and try to look at laws that are in existence in this country or are being proposed. They try to develop better ways of supporting and helping families.
Men and women.

I am particularly incensed that the hon. member would suggest that because the majority of the members of this committee are men, it somehow denigrates the work of this committee. It is as if to suggest that because the majority of members of this House are men, it denigrates all the work of this House.
I am appalled and insulted by those remarks.
She says that too.

Yes, she may say that too and I would not be the least surprised.
I would also like to comment on some of the remarks she has made about this bill's setting up two classes of poor, the deserving poor and the undeserving poor. This is totally wrong. What the bill does is say that those people who are on assistance and are trying to get off assistance should be given some additional support. Those families need that kind of support. They are the ones losing their medicare. For example, when they are off welfare they are losing their dental care, their bus passes for the children. These are significant losses as they try to move into the work force.
This bill has in it a small effort. I am sorry that it is so small but we all know the problem of the availability of money right now. Up to $500 a year is given to those families to assist in that transition. This is certainly not the creation of two classes of poor.

Obviously my comments hit home. I can quote the MP for Calgary North who said "as for national day care we did not kill it. It was done in by a $420 billion debt that resulted from rampant overspending previous to 1984".
This government has set out its priorities very clearly for all Canadians to see. Its priorities continue to be $4.5 billion for 50 Soviet sub-hunting helicopters. Does it not know its geography and recent history? The Soviet Union no longer exists.
It is a matter of priorities. On that I think the member and I agree. It is a matter of priorities and a national child care program which was flaunted as one of the government's major promises to Canadian families for almost a decade now has been scrapped in favour of 50 helicopters. That says it all quite clearly.
In terms of the other comments that he made, there is a lot of evidence on the record of exactly what the family caucus of the Conservative caucus has had to say about women and families. I will quote the member from Delta, British Columbia: "With the rise of special interest groups and their influence in Ottawa, the last people being considered were the families. You have the feminists, the gays and lesbians and all the alternate lifestyles that are demanding attention. We feel that the family is a basic cornerstone of Canadian life".
There are a lot of feminists in this country who will be surprised to know that they are not considered part of their own families. There are a lot of gay people who will be surprised to know that according to the Conservative
September 16, 1992

family caucus, they are not part of their own families. My children will be surprised to know that somehow I am not part of my own family because I am a feminist and proud to be one.

Mr. Speaker, I am glad to have this opportunity to speak in the House on Bill C-80. In particular, I wish to reaffirm the advantages of the integrated child tax benefit over our present family support system. I also wish to refute some erroneous criticism made by opposition members and statements circulating in this Chamber and in the media.
Canada's social programs are something our country and its people are very proud of. They are one of the things that put Canada ahead of other countries and are envied throughout the world. Nevertheless, we cannot avoid the fact that the present family benefits system has serious problems that can and must be solved.
As was pointed out to us in this debate on Bill C-80, the integrated child tax benefit will significantly increase the aid given to families and improve the mechanism for delivering this assistance. The new benefit will strengthen the existing programs, better meet the needs of Canadian families and better respond to changes in their situation. That is why we must ensure that this bill passes. Given the difficulties with the present regime, our constituents, especially low income families, would suffer if we did not pass it.
Let me present these problems succinctly. Clearly, the present benefits do not provide enough support for low-income families to raise their children properly. Furthermore, these benefits are provided separately through three different mechanisms and at different times of the year. Each of these programs has different eligibility criteria, which are confusing to many Canadians.
In addition, the benefits are not well targeted. Families with similar incomes can receive different levels of support, since the benefits are taxable and reclaimed on the basis of individual income.
Furthermore, the system fails to provide adequate support for families who get off welfare to join the ranks of the labour force. These families are often penalized financially when they decide to go back to work, because
Government Orders
of unforeseen job-related expenses and the loss of welfare payments.
Benefit mechanisms may also be a source of problems for many low-income families. As my colleagues have pointed out, the refundable tax credit always comes after the fact, which means the cheque does not reach recipients at a time when they really need it. As a result, money that was supposed to help families goes to tax discounters who are prepared to pay these benefits in advance in return for a certain percentage of the cheque when it is cashed.
The government is not making this up to justify introducing the integrated tax child benefit. Hon. members opposite preferred to ignore these problems in this debate, but they are a major part of the concerns raised by a large number of Canadians and national interest groups. These Canadians want solutions and the integrated child tax benefit is the solution.
During the next five years, the integrated child tax benefit will provide an additional $2.1 billion in support, as well as the current benefits enjoyed by families in Canada. Opposition members should welcome this development.
The integrated child tax benefit will also ensure that these improved benefits are paid to the families who need them most. For instance, 80 per cent of this new money will be paid to families with an annual income of less than $40,000. The new benefit will include an earned income supplement of up to $500.
This new supplement will help ease the transition for low income families who are getting off welfare to enter the labour market. At the present time many families that enter the labour market are often faced with financial problems caused by job related expenses and a potential reduction in their welfare payments.
Furthermore, there will be no more delays in child benefit payments. The integrated child tax benefit will take the form of a monthly payment, thus providing a more practical response to the needs of Canadian children and their parents, and tax discounters will no longer pocket a percentage of these benefits because parents are desperate for cash.
Furthermore, the integrated child tax credit will better reflect changes that occur within the family. Monthly payments will take into consideration any changes in the

Government Orders
family such as the birth of a child or permanent loss of income as a result of marriage break-up.
The integrated child tax benefit will treat all families equally. Benefits will be targeted on the basis of family income rather than individual income. Accordingly, families with similar incomes will receive similar benefits.
Finally, the confusion caused by the present system will be eliminated. The integrated child tax benefit will be delivered by a single mechanism, instead of by three as for the previous one, and only one eligibility criterion will apply, compared to three before. The benefit will be paid in a single monthly non-taxable cheque. The government will automatically calculate the amount of benefits on the basis of income and family situation. To receive benefits, parents will no longer have to do special calculations on their income tax return. And parents with higher income will no longer receive benefits that they will have to pay back when they complete their income tax return. As a result, the income tax return will be shorter and less confusing.
In summary, the integrated child tax benefit is the answer to the changes that interest groups and individuals have been demanding from the government. For example, Canadians have been calling for a simpler tax system, and that is just what the integrated child tax benefit does. They have also been asking for a streamlining of government aid for families and a substantial increase in the amount of this assistance; the integrated child tax benefit meets these objectives.
That is why I have trouble understanding why my hon. colleagues on the other side of the House do not give this bill unanimous support. It makes me think that some of their criticisms are more politically motivated than real objections to the bill.
On universality, in particular, I cannot see how they can object to redirecting benefits from higher income families to those with low and modest incomes, since these families are in greater need. Is that not the real purpose of redistributing wealth? We must keep in mind that 3.1 million families, or 84 per cent of all families with children, will continue to receive benefits. All families with incomes under $50,000 will receive the
same level of benefits or more than they do now. On average, these families will receive $250 more a year per child.
Opposition members were also quick to criticize the indexing of the integrated child tax benefit, because like all other components of the tax system, indexing will be limited to price increases above 3 per cent. They claim that for this reason families will receive less and less aid from year to year.
In making such statements my colleagues on the other side of the House have decided to ignore the facts. In particular, they say that this government has cut $3.5 billion from the Canadian family support system since 1986 as a result of partial deindexation. That is incorrect and misleading. They deliberately fail to mention that this government increased the refundable child tax credit on four occasions since 1985. Such tax breaks have ensured that the benefits intended for all low income families increased at the same rate as inflation. Add to that the $213 supplement for children under seven years of age for whom no child care expense deduction is claimed, and the rate of increase of low income families' benefits actually was higher than that of inflation.
In closing, I urge all the members of this House to support this bill. We should not allow political considerations to foil any plan to try and ensure that every child in Canada can lead a healthy, productive and satisfying life.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank my colleague for Hochelaga-Maisonneuve for the many positive comments he made about this important piece of legislation.
I want the House and those who are watching us to know that our government has great concern about the whole area of human resource development in our country. This ranges from the health condition of the pregnant mother to children to education that is carried on through to retraining and that whole area. Children are of great concern and are greatly studied by our government.
September 16, 1992

Government Orders
Reflecting on the patchwork of child allowances and tax credits and so on, we have great concern with all of that. This is certainly so with lower income people who had to fill out tax forms to receive those moneys. Some were subjected to tax discounters. That is sad and inappropriate. They should not have had to resort to that. It was a result of needing those moneys on a monthly basis and not some time later after filling out complicated forms. Again, they went for this to the tax discounters.
People have come to me, as they probably have to my colleague who is the member for Hochelaga-Maison-neuve who just spoke. They asked: "Why are we receiving child allowances when they should go to people who are more in need".
I want to make those comments and ask him if he would relate some of the conversations he had with his constituents. I know that that is where it is coming from. I feel very confident, as I know he does, with this legislation. It is something Canadians want.
I guess the opposition will always take exception to whatever legislation is brought in. That is the adversarial political system we have in Canada and it is something that has always been there and will continue.
I know we are all here today to make sure that accurate statements and information about this bill is brought forward.
I just make those comments to my honoured colleague and ask for his thoughts.

Mr. Speaker, I have a comment to make. I have been working with the public for a number of years and discussions were reported to me on several occasions by industrials, lawyers, solicitors, all that crowd. I keep in touch with them and recently they were telling me how insane it would be for people of their standing to receive that kind of money. They would rather that it went to the low and middle income families.
This confirms what people have been telling me all along. The main thing is for Bill C-80 to go through as quickly as possible.

Mr. Speaker, I want to indicate at the outset that I shall be sharing my time with my colleague who is the member for Davenport.
I want to make a couple of corrections, though. I know my colleague had no intention of not recognizing this. There is co-operation on occasion in the House. It just so happens that when we feel there is legislation that has not been presented in a forthright kind of way, we feel an obligation to correct the facts. The most recent event, of course, is the co-operation that was displayed with the constitutional proposals.
My colleague also mentions human resources development. I want to talk about that during the few minutes that I have at my disposal. Let us look at the financial facts of this particular bill.
The government continues to refuse to admit that it has reduced child care benefits by $3.5 billion over time. It is now returning, it is true, $400 million. However, that is roughly 12 per cent of what it has removed.
Look at it this way. Supposing I hired you for $100 a day and for a number of reasons I reduced that to $50. You would probably be somewhat unhappy as are some of the people here. Lo and behold, three months, six months or perhaps a year later I come back and say: "I want to give you a 12 per cent raise". Using the figures that I have just utilized that would be $6.
I could claim that I am really a great guy, a great employer and generous. I have just given you a 12 per cent raise. I forgot to remind myself that I had already cut your salary by a substantial amount.
This is the kind of game that is going on over here and that is why some of us are upset. Let us look at the process as well. There were a few hearings. When were they held? During the summer. When is the legislation being presented to the House? It is at this particular point in time and with time allocation. We are being limited in terms of time today.
It is being pushed through at a time when Canadians are really quite concerned about the economic health of this nation, about keeping a job, about the future for themselves and their children and about our great

Government Orders
constitutional crisis. The propaganda machine has much more opportunity to function.
The government has had some success in making people believe that there is more money. That is what really angers me a great deal. It is also an election strategy. Anyone who does not see it that way should really go to an optometrist or some other person to check out their insides. This is an election strategy.
The government is pretending that there is a lot more than there really is. There is a lot more. It is stacking the money at roughly election time because the system currently in place will continue and then the new system will come in. It will give the illusion that all of a sudden you have a lot more money than you had.
By the time one realizes the reality. Zap. It will be a little bit like the Canada-U.S. agreement. Hey, everybody was going to be better off and richer. It was going to be great. One can talk to those 1.6 million Canadians and ask them how great that was.
There is the goods and services tax. It was going to make us more competitive. It was going to do wonderful things for us. One can talk to Canadians and ask them what kinds of wonderful things it has done for them.
The government is creating an impression of more when there is not any more. There is actually less. It is trying to create an impression that it cares. I have no doubt that there are members who care. I do not want to suggest that that is not so.
I have no doubt that most care. In fact, I have no doubt that most of my colleagues on the government side do not understand this legislation. That is why they are getting up there with so much enthusiasm and being so upset when we criticise it.
If one doubts what I am saying, let me just remind my colleagues about a few broken promises. Child care was promised. It is no longer promised. It is gone. There are cuts to education. It was the Prime Minister himself who said he would not tamper with the transfer formula. He did not tamper with it. He smashed it with a 2 per cent reduction, a 1 per cent reduction, and a freeze. In over 10 years that will mean 10 billion fewer dollars for education. By the way, that same tampering with that formula will produce 20 billion fewer dollars for health during that period of time. It seems to me that health
and education are a couple of crucial, critical, fundamental programs of our country.
Not only has the government reduced these benefits that we are talking about in Bill C-80. It has reduced the funding for education by $10 billion over 10 years and reduced the funding for health by $20 billion over 10 years.
What about youth employment? I have talked about youth employment today. This summer was the worst summer we ever had with 17.9 per cent of youth unemployed. There were few jobs. Those who got jobs, and there were many who did not get any, got short-term jobs and they poorly remunerated jobs.
Thming to the GST on books and reading materials, most of the people I know who are paying GST on books for educational purposes are children and youth, young men and women. What does that say about the government's sensitivity toward young people, toward human resource and development?
What about student aid? I have not talked about student aid yet, have I? There is a 3 per cent tax on the people who need to borrow because they are poor. That is quite a record, is it not, and another six months' interest? We were promised that with the six months' interest the 3 per cent tax would be removed, but lo and behold the 3 per cent tax is still there.
The government became a little nervous and thought it had better not start fooling around with six months more of interest until it had removed that 3 per cent tax. It also forgot to tell us-and that is my own estimates and of course no one would deny them when I raised them-that six months more of interest would produce roughly twice as much money as the 3 per cent tax did. What a game.
I can see all those colleagues who are business people on the other side really coming forward and appreciating the significance of their business acumen when they start giving us those kinds of things.
The government says it is attempting to control the deficit and the debt. The deficit this year is over $30 billion and the debt is roughly $425 billion. The government loves to say that it was the Liberals who did it. A former finance minister, the hon. member for Etobicoke Centre, told me-I have a letter in writing-that it was $167.8 billion at the end of 1984. Now if we take the interest from that time to now we find there is no way
September 16, 1992

that it becomes $425 billion. Another smoke and mirror scheme. It offloads to provinces and tries to tell us that it controls its expenditures.
Let us look at this. I have $100,000 worth of debt. I walk into my family and say to my wife that I have $10,000 for her and $10,000 each for my three daughters.
I am now down to $60,000. I give my brothers each $10,000 and all of a sudden I have $10,000 worth of debt and I say: "I am a great manager. What business acumen I have. What tremendous insight I possess".
This is what is happening here. The government talks about controlling expenditures. It has controlled them, but off the backs of whom? The children, the students, the health care system and the educational system. That is what has happened.
We talk about the deficit and the debt that are out of control. I have many other things I wanted to mention.

I wanted to talk about the Canadian tax system which penalizes the poor. I wanted to talk about how the rich benefit from it. There are still quite a few profitable corporations that do. That is most unfortunate. I did not get to talk about the unemployed, the social assistance recipients and the food bank users.

I want to close with a plea. It is in a letter from the Canadian Federation of Students. It refers to Bill C-80 and reads as follows:
This legislation will seriously affect student parents, especially those who are also users of the Canada Student Loans Program.
Under the current situation, student parents receive family allowance which counts as income when they apply for a Canada student loan. They also receive child tax credits, either in the form of a prepayment in November, or in the spring after submitting their income tax form. The proposed new program will hurt student parents in two ways.
First, instead of receiving the two types of assistance described above, student parents will receive one monthly cheque only.
It continues:
For student parents, the timing of the prepayment provided necessary funds for the period of time between the end of the first term and the beginning of the second term, and very necessary funds for the Christmas season. Timing is also a serious concern for those student
Government Orders
parents who currently receive their child tax benefits during the summer.
This time of the year is also one in which many students find themselves crucially short of funds. This situation is especially problematic in times such as these when student unemployment rates are at record highs.
They make a plea for a full examination of this program because they realize, as I do, that it will hurt many Canadians in spite of claims to the contrary from government. In spite of the claims to the contrary, it will hurt many individuals.

Mr. Speaker, I have a rather simple question but I think it is important to get some clarification. The opposition has said many times that because of deindexation $3.5 billion has been cut from child benefits. However it ignores all the enrichments to the child tax credit over the last seven years.
Since 1985 the government has increased the refundable child tax credit four times and has introduced a supplement of $213 for children under seven years where child care expenses are not claimed. These enrichments have ensured that the average level of federal child benefits paid to low income families has more than kept pace with inflation.
The child tax credit will increase child assistance by $2.1 billion over five years. This increase will be over and above the benefits that would have been provided if the current programs had remained in place.
In addition to this $2.1 billion increase in benefits, the government is committed to review the level of payments over time and increase them as fiscal conditions permit as it has done with the refundable child tax credit.
I wonder if the hon. member would not be a little more forthcoming and honest with the Canadian public and not compare apples to oranges. He is taking numbers spread over many years and comparing with one year and shuffling the deck on people. If he wants to criticize what the government has been doing, would he give a clear and precise accounting of what he is saying?

Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for the question. I believe that I am forthright and honest. Actually I do not believe that anything I have said here was misleading.

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
I would like Canadians to decide whose figures they trust more. I indicated that not only was $3.5 billion taken out and $400 million reinstated. I talked about their supposed reformed tax system that is not helping the poor. I also talked about the reductions to health and education. It will be $30 billion.
If my colleague wants to talk numbers, let us look at the totality of it. Let us look at what has been added and what has been taken out. I assure my colleague that if I am wrong I will apologize publicly in his home town before the largest audience he can find for me. At the most critical time possible for him, even if it was on his nomination night or his election night I shall displace myself to be with him.
I wanted to make another point. Let us look at the totality of what has been removed in health, education and other programs and let us look at what has been put in because I know there has been a serious reduction. Let us also look at the need today.
Depending upon whose figures, and they vary, from four million to five million Canadians are at the level of poverty or below. That is what we have currently today. I will go with four million; frankly it makes me feel better. There are one million among those four million or five million who are children.
We have to look at the need. The need is greater today than it has ever been. We cannot simply look at resourcing in a vacuum. We need to look at it from a need perspective.
If we look at food banks today, as I mentioned before over two million Canadians will be fed at food banks this year. I believe and I stand to be corrected, and I want to be corrected if I am wrong, that 40 per cent of those are young people and children.
Just to summarize, I know my colleague is well intentioned and I know that he believes a lot in what is being done here. The reduction in the number of the programs is a positive one. The targeting has some merits. I acknowledge that. Where we have some difficulties and some differences of opinion is in the amount of funding that has been removed for health, education and child benefits over time. I did not even talk about the capping on social assistance and the impact it would have.
If my colleague wants to challenge me to a public debate I will go to his riding and I will talk about these reductions. I will do so with a great deal of enthusiasm.

Mr. Speaker, let me at the outset thank my colleague from St. Boniface for his generosity and congratulate him on his impassioned speech. I also congratulate our critic, the member for Winnipeg North Centre, on his very fine intervention earlier this afternoon.
We as Liberals have a very long and fine tradition of focusing our attention and speaking up for the cause of the poor, of the unemployed and of the defenceless. We have done that over the decades under several prime ministers and in opposition.
Therefore the House will understand why in this debate in the last three days we have focused particularly on that part of the bill which abandons and overlooks the situation of poverty as experienced by children and their parents. There is no doubt that is the weak point of this particular legislation.
This is not just a partisan consideration. May I draw to your attention, Mr. Speaker, the view expressed by Dr. Ken Battle of the Caledon Institute of Social Policy when he said: "The federal government's proposal to change child benefits is seriously flawed. It does little in the short term and virtually nothing over the long term to make a dent in child poverty. Clearly this is pre-election reform since the larger monthly payments will come onstream during the election year. The new child benefit and earned income supplement will be paid monthly and so will look much bigger than the present system since the current refundable child credit is paid annually or for poor families twice a year".
This is a statement from someone who has no particular axe to grind, so to speak.
In addition to Dr. Battle, at committee stage the minister of social services for British Columbia, Joan Smallwood, spoke in a very critical manner of this bill. So did the Citizens for Public Justice from my own city of Toronto, the Social Planning Council of Metropolitan Toronto, the Child Poverty Action Group, and Trevor Williams from Family Services Canada.
September 16, 1992

We definitely have here a serious shortcoming which we in the Liberal Party, with our tradition, must and will continue to address.
What strikes a listener to this debate is the fact that the present emerging phenomenon of child poverty in this country is attributable to two major factors. One is unemployment among youth and the other one is the fact that wealth is not redistributed the way it should be distributed in our society. Therefore there is a need to look at tax reform that would better achieve distribution of wealth among the Canadian population.
At the present time it is extremely disturbing to leam that in metro Toronto, Ontario, and I suspect in other parts of the country, youth unemployment is around 19 per cent to 20 per cent. This is an historical high, unfortunately, and it is a figure that ought to send a shiver down the collective spine of this government in terms of a profound preoccupation with a phenomenon that ought to be dealt with on the basis of an urgent matter that requires urgent action. Instead, we have seen a reduction in job creation programs for youth over the last two summers. We have seen a sense of indifference to various demands being made from the opposition benches to improve the employment situation, particularly in the summer months for the unemployed youth from coast to coast.
Bill C-80 somehow inevitably prods us to raise these factors or these questions because in a way child poverty is related, as I mentioned a moment ago, both to the fact that employment is so hard to be found and that we have reached a point, through tax measures introduced over the last eight years by the Progressive Conservative government, in which the taxation system considerably favours high income earners and disfavours the lower income earners. In that respect we find the plight of those who are struggling with poverty, and particularly our younger people.
It is interesting to note that in this House of Commons, and the member for Cape Breton Highlands- Canso reminded us of that two days ago, a resolution was passed in 1989 calling for the elimination of child poverty by the year 2000. Therefore it is understandable that we should be asking the government why it did not take advantage of this measure, Bill C-80 before us, to introduce or include the elements that would permit moving toward the elimination of child poverty. Obvious-
Govemment Orders
ly this would have been and is the natural vehicle to tackle that particular social issue.
The goal of the elimination of child poverty cannot be resolved only by way of benefits. We are the first ones to recognize it. However, certainly it is a very important instrument in the arsenal of measures and programs that the federal government can develop to tackle this particular problem.
In reviewing the way that this measure was received one might also want to add, as some of my colleagues have already done, the fact that of the witnesses who appeared before the committee in studying this legislation only 1 out of 25 was in a position to speak in support, and in favourable terms, of the measure itself. Does that not say something? Is that not indicative of something that does not meet the requirements of Canadians at large who are preoccupied with the problem of child poverty? Obviously it is an indicator that something is missing from this particular legislation.
I believe very profoundly that the absence of measures that would address child poverty is a reflection of a lack of political will. This measure has been drafted by civil servants, but on instructions from their political masters. If the political masters had indicated very clearly from the outset that the question of child poverty in Canada ought to be addressed through Bill C-80 we would not be today debating its shortcomings in this respect.
We are now heading for a winter. We are heading for not only seasonal high unemployment but by all forecasts for high unemployment that will unfortunately last for a year or two. This bill offers us, once again, the opportunity to raise in this House the damage caused to the social fibre by high youth unemployment and by the fact that we are in a way borrowing from the future at their expense, and the necessity to once again and further press the government to introduce the necessary measures to specifically deal with youth unemployment if it wants to gets to the roots of the question of child poverty.

I listened with interest to my friend from Davenport, who I have a great deal of respect for, and I was wondering why he would support avoiding this bill. After all, the bill eliminates the family allowance, which is $36 a month, and the small $65 deduction people get off their income tax toward supporting a child and amalgamates it all in a new child tax credit system in one payment that comes to people every month. It gives them spending money every

September 16, 1992
Government Orders
month, and it is not the kind of spending money that can be taken away by a tax discounter.
This is obviously a far better bill than the current present system. Is he saying that he and his party want to defend the current system, or are they not prepared to look at a new system that puts more money in the hands of people with kiddies? This bill puts $400 million next year and $2.1 billion over five years into the hands of people with kids in Canada. Why would they not want to do that? Why would they object to that?
I agree that there is child poverty and we should possibly do more. Why would the member criticize what we are doing? Why would he not vote for what we are doing and say do more? Why would he want to throw it all away? Would he rather have the existing system and forget it all?

Mr. Speaker, the member for Mississauga South is usually very incisive and provocative in his interventions, and I welcome them.
Time did not permit me to deal with the second reason that we find this bill objectionable. That reason is that this bill begins to erode, if not eliminate, the concept of universality. The concept of universality is one which the Liberal Party of Canada introduced and still cherishes today because it is the better approach. It treats everybody in the same manner at the moment of distribution of wealth but it then retrieves the funds that have been given to those who are more fortunate in society through the income tax system.
The income tax system, as the member for Mississauga South would confirm, because he knows it probably better than most in this House, has over the recent years lost its capacity to redistribute wealth as it used to. As a result of that, people who have continued to do well and improve their standing in society and people who are at the lower end of the income scale find their positions slipping and losing ground at the rate which is the source of profound preoccupation. Therefore, if we want social stability I would be inclined to think that any party worth its salt should raise a very strong voice in this Chamber to say that a measure for child benefit that leaves out
Canadians at the low end of the income scale is not a good measure. A measure which does away with universality is also not a good measure.
As the member for Winnipeg North Centre outlined earlier, we have in society these days unexpected layoffs, sudden economic changes where people find themselves from one year to the next in dire economic straits. Under this bill, they would have to wait a considerable length of time before they can be covered under the new system in a manner that protects the income of their children.
I am grateful to the member for Mississauga South for having allowed me, in a sense, to outline the second line of reasoning as to why we find this bill lacking and not deserving support.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to speak on the Children's Special Allowances Act. I did have the opportunity a little earlier to make some observations and I will attempt to make some more.
